author: {'steamid': '76561198010177709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 2241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 492, 'last_played': 1706018566}
review:
This must be one of the worst tower defense games on Steam. This is what Revenge of the Titans is about: player gets punished for playing. 

This game is a great example how not to design a videogame 101.

- Your cash carries to the next mission: Cash saved up a lot? Difficulty spikes hard. Did not save much? Lacks enough to defend all fronts in the next mission.

- Little modules to make towers stronger: Not used? Towers are too weak to kill anyone. Use too much? Expensive and space used too much to build more towers.

- Thereâ€™s a spec tree: Carefully built to counter next mission? Time to re-spec again every time you start a mission. Well balanced distribution? Mission gets much harder.

It is incredibly difficult to find the fine balance. The developer had this certain numbers in mind that is not revealed to the player on any level. The game just feels like it punishes you either way and you are just barely passing when you â€œwinâ€. Where exactly is the fun in that?

Enemy spawns are random. They do not follow path the developers drew themselves on the map. They scatter around and there are no elements to reroute these enemies.

There is no right or wrong action. There is only punishable action, and every action is punished.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041760319', 'num_games_owned': 1703, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1678815706}
review:
As a distinguished member of the defence force against aliens I cant recommend this game.

Presentation is excellent but the game is massively flawed by bad design choices and random nature of enemies. You can't plan or be strategic as with most tower defence games because you will be punished for it by them chucking more enemies at you in the next level with the only option being build random shit and hope for the best. Play it like a casual clueless person and it can be fun, play with strategy and you will be screwed.

Nah bruv, this aint it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960783864', 'num_games_owned': 464, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1675538432}
review:
I quite enjoy tower defense style games, however this is not really tower defense. Too much on the fly panic building and not enough planning and strategy to be considered a true tower defense game. 

Waves are inconsistent, they appear with random amounts of enemies and at random locations and don't follow any set path. While the art style is very sleek, the enemies all look too similar.

Difficulty scales with cash on hand, and perhaps this feature was added as an anti-cheat, but all it ends up doing is encouraging you to spend frivolously. If you haven't teched into an enemy counter then you just straight lose, and enemies will begin to spawn to counter your tech choices.

In the end, it seems the game seeks to punish you for playing, and that's not fun.

It bothers me a little, but I've come to live with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198190167441', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 747, 'last_played': 1661175152}
review:
The game is good until the point that you realize that it's all scripted. So if you decide to do your best, and strategize all your moves in such a way that you'll save as much money as possible for the next round, you'll actually make things worse for yourself, since the game will be way harder after that.

So in short, if you're too good at this game, it's not enjoyable, but if you just play it "for fun", it's surely for you.

I've played this game almost 10 years ago, and I really enjoyed it, but not this time. Because it seemed like I only got bad at it, which is untrue and not fair.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017974699', 'num_games_owned': 440, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1742, 'last_played': 1664403332}
review:
You may have seen the other top-rated reviews on this game, stating that it flies in the face of many reasonable game design decisions for most tower defense games, and that this game's saving grace is its immense amount of charm and bangin' soundtrack.

These other top-rated reviews are spot on. Revenge of The Titans is not a particularly good Tower Defense game in the traditional sense. Despite that, I still recommend this game emphatically. Those 29 hours on record were spread out over [i]ten years[/i], not including unlogged hours, since I own a non-Steam copy as well. This game's charm alone has made me come back to it over and over again. I still find myself humming the techno-classical remixes when I go about my day. I still immediately recognise when Puppygames' style when I'm idly looking for new releases. This game runs just as well, [i]if not better[/i], on my low-end daily Linux machine, today, as it did on the family computer, which was the style back when this game came out.

This game is not a particularly good tower defence game, because when you hear "tower defence" you probably think of knowing the enemy's path in advance, laying traps and upgrading buildings- This game has none of that. Enemies will move unpredictably and leave roads for seemingly no reason. More than a few janky balancing issues mean that you're punished illogically for doing [i]too well[/i] in a previous level in the campaign, and the game was near unbeatable before the Respec option was added. But the gameplay loop, the second-to-second thinking on your feet to predict what the Titans are thinking- this game has a [i]heart and soul[/i] to it that makes it not for everyone, but definitely worth your time.

But while the game is worth your time, it might not be worth your money. I grade my games' value-for-time as $1 should mean at least 2 hours of enjoyment to be "decently priced", and $1 for 10 to be "good value". At time of review, this game is $30 AUD, for 30 hours of play over the last 10 years. If I were in America, where the price is $15, I might consider that a good price- but if I were to stumble upon this game in post Covid-times? whew.

As much as this game holds a special place in my heart as one of my favourite indie games to sit down and chew over of all time, it's not worth the normal asking price, at least here. The Ultrabundle, which is more expensive but includes a few of the other games from the Puppygames catalogue, is better- but that's not an easy ask if you're not particularly interested in those games either. I got this game as part of the second Humble Bundle, and I can easily say that for the $20+5 other games at the time, it was well worth it.

All in all- wait for this game to go on sale. As much as I adore it, and come back to it time and time again, it's priced a bit too highly to subsist on charm alone. It's been an unfortunately long while since that's happened (Puppygames seems to have not participated in the last 2 Steam Seasonal Sales, but I don't blame them considering the economic situtation >_>), but there's always the future.

As an aside: I miss when they used to do Demos. I tried out a lot of their games before eventually buying most of them in a bundle, and the main reason why I haven't bought Welcome to Basingstoke is because I don't know if I'll like it, and I end up forgetting about it whenever I have the money to buy a new game :c

author: {'steamid': '76561198136678645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 2192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1708, 'last_played': 1703550317}
review:
One of the most challenging tower defense games!
-What makes this unique? The game completely adapts you. It is like the AI anticipates and knows how to respond to you like a chess match. For example, the more money you start with, the more enemies and further away resources are from you
-Enemies do not travel a straight path. They actually adapt to where you place your towers and look for the WEAKEST point. Therefore, you have to choose wisely and youtube videos may not help as the map adapts to you
-Many different enemies. The most annoying one is the one on level 44 that has armor and can shoot your towers from a distance!
-If Kingdom rush is 10/10, I would place this as 9/10 as it can be frustrating from time to time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198284731206', 'num_games_owned': 1603, 'num_reviews': 503, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1652940824}
review:
[h1]No pause, all go![/h1]
This game has no pause, no 'lanes' to speak of, and honestly can't be called a 'tower defense' at all. The fact that the game can't be paused is the biggest issue I have with this game by far. When each level starts, the monsters start coming IMMEDIATELY... you haven't even got time to think of where you're gonna place your buildings or where the 'best spots' are, you just have to start placing them, else you're gonna lose. So that's a huge issue... the 2nd biggest issue is the fact that the game doesn't have 'lanes' like 99% of tower defense games have, so the enemies often come from ALL directions and don't follow a set path, so you have to throw your buildings in the way of them and just hope you've placed enough defences to hold up against them... if not, then the enemies simply break your sh|t and you have to redo the level. Because of that, the best strategy in the game by far, is to built the Robot units, because they literally pursue the enemies anywhere on the map and they can't be killed (unlike your buildings). So literally the best strategy in the game, involves NOT building static defences, and that's just hilarious in a game that's in the TD genre supposedly. So, is there anything good about the game? Yeah... the music is good. That's it... but if the devs wanted to, then they could fix the above 2 missteps and have a very good game on their hands... but as it sits currently, I can't recommend the game.

For more reviews, visit my curator page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7851637/
For my full recommended list of games: https://steamcommunity.com/id/lfpg/recommended/

Highly Recommended!

review:
Too easy at the beginning of the game and requires annoying micromanagement. 
Few info about tec & turrets. What am I tecing in? Why is this thing blowing up my own units? 
Enemies used to be different, but... meh. 
Why do we need economy upgrades? 
The tech tree is disgusting.

The game looks good, but damn, I haven't played something this boring in a long time. Try hiring a game designer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198323260530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 5350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1675559041}
review:
If you are new to tower defense games, you will like "Revenge of the Titans" - it is one of the best.  I found it a little difficult to figure out what to do in the beginning (not sure why, but there are a lot of concise instructions available now).  Watching game play by someone else was not helpful to me.  It is, in the end, a fairly standard tower defense game.  You have a base to defend.  Titans come from all directions, but mostly follow roads, at least at some point in their approach to your tower.  You have turrets to place along the way, and obstacles to slow them down.  Money has to be collected from nearby ore to fund the building of the towers, which are constantly getting destroyed by the titans or getting depleted of ammunition.  

No doubt one of the pros is the beautiful artwork.  Very simple, but elegant coupled with synthesized famous classical music pieces (can't go wrong with these, but they have to blend, and here they do).  This makes for a pleasant experience.  The story, though simple, is told in a comedic way that makes it entertaining.  There aren't many cons, but one is that the buildup of your upgrades (research) is a slow process and only one is allowed per level.  If you go back, you can get a different one, but you can't build up strength by re-playing previous levels (at least in my experience).  You can get stuck on a level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198173381281', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 1103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1103, 'last_played': 1562973389}
review:
Revenge of the Titans is a peculiar beast, a kind of evolved Tower Defence or RTS-lite, with the insubstantial air of a superior noughties Flash game that belies the campaignâ€™s length and difficulty. Giant monsters from â€“ yes â€“ Titan are invading Earth, and after pushing them back from the motherworld, mankind takes to space and battles them across the solar system. Beginning manageably enough with a few lanes of incoming foes with predictable habits, the final levels feature hordes of agile enemies that will evade or steamroller your thin defensive line. Combined with bonuses that must be clicked to collect, ghost enemies that must be manually zapped, a variety of other foes who will resist various elements of your defence, and vast combat arenas with no mini-map or other form of strategic oversight, I confess the burden of clunky micro-management compelled me to give up just shy of the campaignâ€™s conclusion. Persistent progression also involves a slowly-unlocked tech tree thatâ€™s easy to stuff up, cash carried over between levels that scales enemy numbers, and super-weapon bonuses that carry over between levels as well as being vulgarly available in exchange for your real-world email. These pay-to-win-adjacent balancing headaches feel unwelcome in what is essentially a full-price, single-player experience.

Revenge of the Titans is, however, elevated by handsome retro-futurist stylings that see your little towers and robot warriors pew-pew-ing away at the invading Titan army and your flickering CRT screen fuzz with static when a boss lands on your headquarters. The soundtrack is also great, a chiptune rendition of Holstâ€™s famous planet suite, and the sound design in general is top notch. The campaign is surprisingly well-written, and developers arenâ€™t afraid to season the game with peculiarly British humour. These thoughtful touches preserve goodwill where some of Revenge of the Titansâ€™ design decisions might otherwise frustrate. Overall, this is an inessential, fun, somewhat problematic little RTS that will run comfortably on a pocket calculator, and can be cautiously recommended to the interested player.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986527965', 'num_games_owned': 726, 'num_reviews': 412, 'playtime_forever': 800, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 800, 'last_played': 1473271648}
review:
A flawed tower defense game.

Some of your money persists from level to level, so the better you do, the more money you'll have in the future. Unfortunately the game counterbalances this by making the level more difficult. If you do too well on too many levels in a row, you can essentially bump the level difficulty to near impossible to win. So you gotta win, but don't do too well, that's bad. Does that make any sense? No, but that's the way it is here.

Eventually 'smart' enemies start showing up. Basically these enemies will go off path to go around your towers, making some or a large part of your defenses useless. This also means that restarting levels becomes near pointless. The enemies went around my defenses here, so I'll restart and place those defenses somewhere else. Oh, they just went around them again. The enemies went after my poorly defended refineries instead of my base, guess I'll restart and add more defenses at the refineries. Oh, the enemies ignored my refineries and went straight for my not as well defended main base.

There're plenty of other issues as well.

Also of note is that the developer commented on someone else's review and apparently was upset and 'believes' that someone who has never designed a game can't/shouldn't point out objectively bad design issues with it. That level of stupidity is just sad.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997555711', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1615409894}
review:
The artstyle, like all Puppygames games, is great. 
This game is a... Well, copy of Harvest: Massive Encounter, which you can also buy on steam. It has some obvious upgrades: there are more enemy and tower types, there are a bunch of support building you can use to upgrade towers, and even factories that produce units like an RTS... 

Except all the towers are lackluster unless upgraded many times. Unit factories just have units sitting around them, you can't control them, which doesn't make much sense for "The ultimate mash-up of Real-time Strategy and Tower Defense!"

Armored enemies are a constant pain, making you always try to build Blast Towers which have stupidly slow firerate. It makes sense, they're basically AT guns, but not when almost every enemy in later levels has armor.

Enemy paths stop being relevant when "smart" enemies appear, which just means they try to walk around all your defenses, making you spend money to build barricades that break quickly.

Harvesters work incredibly poorly, unless, once again, they are upgraded many times. Harvester upgrades start at the price of two harvesters, and the other two harvester upgrades are even more expensive.

Unlocking new towers isn't even rewarding, since you need to research "Technologies" to unlock towers. Each research uses 1 research point. Later on, the game expects you to know the optimum towers and research you need, which changes per level, which you have no way of knowing unless you try and fail. Repeatedly. I'm still on Titan, the final world, and I can't access nearly a third of the buildings because I don't have enough research points.

Power ups may sometimes appear, but they are all useless except for the Repair one. The money powerups? they give you 100 $. That's it.

This game would be really good if research was a tree and had WAY FEWER useless technology researches, the ability to actually control units from unit factories, and improving how the economy works. But this game is a decade old, so why bother.

author: {'steamid': '76561198804366889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1615238569}
review: Bad Game! Very Little distinction between enemies. Your income is really broken, spend more to get more, but your sources also ran dry not... quickly, but slowly, and gave little reward. resulting in you placing mining in the worst places, defending in weird spots, only you to have built everything there for nothing later in the round. and then going into a money drought. ALSO! the biggest thing in the game that i Despised! the game would do this thing with the screen where it would like phase like a 1960's TV, it honestly gave me kinda a headache. Horrible feature. If you want a game like this, try Mindustry. if your just into Tower defense, try Bloon Tower defense.

review:
Havent played this since I first bought it about 8 years ago, I remember it playing ok as a casual/introductory Tower Defence game, it does pass a few hours pretty decently but I remember getting about 50-70% of the way through but I had to purchase additional content to conitnue so I never completed it, this was a bit of a joke considering I got most of the way through in just 2 hours and then asking for more money was a bit of a joke really. 

Its ok for a couple of hours, if its on a nice discount say around Â£3-4 then it might be worth a lazy night play through, well 70% play through if i remember correctly. At this price I cant recommend, you can rest easy if you decide to pass this one up even if its on discount!

e mais fileiras de tropas tentando segurar o avanÃ§o do inimigo (como em Plants vs Zombies) ou vocÃª tem uma trilha tortuosa por onde o inimigo passa, em torno da qual vocÃª prepara suas defesas (como em Battle of Kings). Apesar das diferenÃ§as, as duas modalidades seguem uma previsibilidade: vocÃª sabe o caminho do invasor.

Revenge of the Titans sacode a fÃ³rmula com uma legiÃ£o de alienÃ­genas que avanÃ§am por padrÃµes desconhecidos pela ciÃªncia. Existem estradas e existem aqueles invasores que obedecem a indicaÃ§Ã£o de caminho, mas a maioria deles faz suas prÃ³prias regras e o resultado Ã© um caos que nÃ£o se dobra ao seu controle em momento algum. Ã‰ o Tower Defense do Inferno, um jogo para se passar raiva e desistir antes de se partir para outra opÃ§Ã£o.

NÃ£o que eu nÃ£o tenha tentado. Minha sorte e minhas habilidades estratÃ©gicas permitiram a liberaÃ§Ã£o da Terra e da Lua das forÃ§as extraterrestres, assim como praticamente Marte inteiro. Apenas as Ãºltimas batalhas marcianas conseguiram dilapidar meus Ãºltimos bastiÃµes de paciÃªncia.

Em sua defesa, Revenge of the Titans apresenta um visual deliciosamente retrÃ´, que nÃ£o enquadra exatamente na estÃ©tica pixelada convencional e puxa mais para uma realidade alternativa onde vocÃª podaria plugar um Gameboy em um televisor de tubo ou algo assim. Essa escolha de design se reflete tambÃ©m na construÃ§Ã£o dos personagens e das unidades que transporta o estilo de Space Invaders duas geraÃ§Ãµes Ã  frente. Ã‰ anacrÃ´nico, mas fascinante o efeito produzido.

Com personagens caricatos dos dois lados do conflito, o jogo nÃ£o se leva a sÃ©rio, atÃ© o momento em que a dificuldade escala e vocÃª percebe que suas mecÃ¢nicas nÃ£o sÃ£o brincadeira.

Com os inimigos avanÃ§ando de forma quase espasmÃ³dica, grana limitada para construir e suas torres sendo tornando um alvo fÃ¡cil entre uma recarga e outra, o campo de batalha deixa de ser divertido bem rÃ¡pido. Revenge of the Titans oferece um Modo Campanha FÃ¡cil, mas meus brios acreditaram (erroneamente) que o modo normal seria o modo correto de aproveitar o jogo como seus desenvolvedores planejaram, embora esses mesmos desenvolvedores estivessem me premiando com Conquistas por ter conseguido fazer isso ou aquilo no "modo mais difÃ­cil". Eu estava dando murros em ponta de faca.

Felizmente, o jogo permite resetar sua Ã¡rvore tecnolÃ³gica a bel-prazer, o que me permitia experimentar diferentes abordagens para neutralizar os Titans. Ainda assim, as Ãºltimas batalhas das quais participei estavam sempre cada vez mais prÃ³ximas daquela que me faria desistir.

Revenge of the Titans nÃ£o Ã© um jogo ruim e conquista pela simpatia. PorÃ©m, ergo aqui minha bandeira branca e permito que o caos triunfe sobre Marte.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11093, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1600235216}
review:
This is a convoluted 2D top down retro pixel tower defense game.  The game features a more open kind of map structure, allowing flexible solutions for each level.  Towers are slightly more complex than typical tower defense games and interact with each other to some extent.

The biggest killer here is the really ugly "retro" graphics which were used as a substitute for modern PC graphics.  It's unclear whether this was due to a lack of talent or a lack of budget from the developer, but the result is the same, awful, ugly visuals that don't faithfully reproduce the PCs we had decades ago, they just look bad.  There's also a screen filter to make things look even worse, but that can be turned off.  Fullscreen mode doesn't work if you have a high def monitor, only displaying the top right hand corner of the screen due to improper management of overscan/DPI scaling from the developers.  Rudimentary testing on any modern PC would have caught this, so it's inexplicable why the developers didn't properly test the game.

Ugly pixel graphics, technical implementation gaffes that make this fall far beneath minimum standard for a modern PC game are enough for this game to be a solid reject, but they're charging a ridiculous $21.50 for this shovelware, that price would get you actual strategy games like Frostpunk or Stellaris, so it's just impossible to recommend this bundlemeat to anyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054805835', 'num_games_owned': 614, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1590121390}
review:
[h1]The aesthetic is great, the gameplay not so much.[/h1]

[b][i]Revenge of the Titans[/i] is a retro-style tower defense game with much more freedom in tower placement and an emphasis on both strategy and tactics.[/b]

At first glance this game seems like a lot of funâ€”it has that retro aesthetic and an interesting skill/upgrade tree so you can progress as you play. No grid means you can place your towers almost anywhere and make tactical decisions mid-round. After a certain point though, the game simply felt unplayable due to the difficulty of the enemies mixed with your limited resources. I thought that the upgrade tree would be free for me to customize, but the game has a specific path it wants you to follow (but it doesn't let you know that), and if you don't upgrade exactly that way then you're screwed and the enemies will decimate you. Even then, the difficulty spike is massive after a certain point and you have to frantically manage your turret placement across the map while the enemies chew up your weak spots.

I might give it another try at some point, but at the moment it's just not very fun to play. If you still think this is your kind of game then go for it.

[h1]Overall Enjoyment:
2/5 â€” Bad
[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198018568632', 'num_games_owned': 500, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1589209895}
review:
[h1]Game Review from 30 Minutes of Play[/h1]
Reminding myself if I should revisit and if you should purchase.

[b]ELEVATOR PITCH: Artsy Tower Defense[/b]
LIKED: The neon-pixel art, theme, and interesting choices in upgrades.
DISLIKED: Alt-Enter to toggle fullscreen/windowed mode is your friend. Some dev decisions like the screen flicker didn't do it for me.

[b]===== Mood After 30mins =====[/b]
â˜ Addicted
â˜ Afternoon delight
â˜‘ Grindfest
â˜ Frustrated

[b]===== Will I Revisit =====[/b]
â˜ Yes, I aim to 100% complete
â˜ Yes, but only beat the game
â˜‘ Eventually. Until then, back to the pile
â˜ No, on to other games

[b]===== Price =====[/b]
â˜ Full price worthy
â˜ Discount
â˜‘ Deep discount
â˜ Pass

[b]Disclaimer:[/b] [i]I'm aware 30 minutes is not enough time to properly review any game. Historically, I'm a big completionist when it comes to gaming, but my backlog will just not die and adulting obligations continue to mount. I needed to find some sense of accomplishment with my backlog other than buying them at great discount. Dedicating at least 30 minutes of play per game will be my arbitrary sense of achievement. It may not justify my gaming spending habits, but I'll suffer less buyer's remorse. Who knows, in 30 minutes I might discover a great game I want to revisit and something you want to purchase. GGs![/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197971263608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1590797532}
review:
This fast-paced tower defense builds on RTS research-driven mechanics with a retro visual style that still feels modern.  The onscreen artifacts and frenetic pace of each level make for exciting gameplay.  Click-and-drag to build several of the same building in whatever pattern the pointer moves; sell buildings in the same manner.  Interactions between campaign levels allow for advances in research.

My favorite part is the dialogue with the stellar voice acting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030123832', 'num_games_owned': 339, 'num_reviews': 345, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1587902179}
review: It's a fairly cute tower defence, but I have some gripes. The vast majority of the skill tree is prerequisites for other upgrades that do nothing on their own. Because money carries over between missions, much of the gameplay is trying to squeeze just a little more cash out of the map so you're in a better position later. This kind of min-maxing might appeal to some, but I lost interest pretty quickly.

review:
A creative mix of Tower Defense and Real-Time Strategy, for sure. It's pretty damn addicting, too.
If you want an interesting game with a fun concept, this is the place to turn.

Also, the game's difficulty ramps up fast by increasing the enemy's intelligence, rather than flat increases to health, speed and damage.

7.3/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025003452', 'num_games_owned': 1076, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 2549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2549, 'last_played': 1576978573}
review:
A fun and challenging tower defense game. The later worlds will essentially require that you've developed the most efficient strategy though, so you'll hit a roadblock until you can do that. The levels do remain challenging once you've mastered that (though the early levels will be very easy if you learn it early in the game), but there's also some bullshit flying monsters that'll drop a bomb a mile away when they die.

Other than that, it's pretty fun, and there's a challenging bonus mode during Christmas.

EDIT: Years later, I still listen to some of the songs from the soundtrack sometimes

author: {'steamid': '76561198046569932', 'num_games_owned': 119, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1577019614}
review: Revenge of the Titans is an enjoyable Tower Defense campaign. It has a campaign in which you can research new upgrades and tower types between levels in a style that reminded me of Starcraft 2. Each level is harder than the one before, but even on the hardest difficulty setting, I didn't find it very difficult until the last couple levels. The story doesn't have any substance but is mildly entertaining. Overall, it's a pretty fun game but doesn't compare well the the RTS games it is clearly aspiring to imitate.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962209449', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1567457131}
review:
This game is not bad, but it's way too frustrating. 

Unlike most of the TD games, enemies here do not really follow a fixed path. That leads to horrendous situations in which you built your towers either 10 meters too far (out of range, not attacking anything and being a waste of money) or worse, 10 meters too close (being in the enemies' path, melting like butter in the sun). Add the fact that in most levels, enemies pop from all corners of the map, that you don't have time for reflection at the beginning of a level, and that the skills tree which seems promising at first is actually bland and boring.

Close to "Yes", but still a "No-no".

author: {'steamid': '76561197974484281', 'num_games_owned': 2311, 'num_reviews': 1398, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1561736910}

author: {'steamid': '76561198418549470', 'num_games_owned': 1152, 'num_reviews': 650, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1587742429}
review:
Fairly decent tower defense game, although it shows a bit of its age here. The best part of the game is the keeping with the PuppyGame themed droids, from their other games. The scifi-spoof upgrades are pretty fun, and the units are cute, too. Some very nice lighting effects, where you can see how that evolved into the Basingstoke game. But for all the game's charm, it does not hold my attention for very long, and it is built to be a campaign game.

Since the game is often on sale, it might be worth a purchase, to support a great indie developer. The game works great on linux desktops, and the developer is a long-time linux game supporter, too. You might have a better time with it, because I am not really the biggest fan of traditional tower defense games, either. The game uses a Java game engine, and it takes up 450 MBs of diskspace.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998455758', 'num_games_owned': 1566, 'num_reviews': 1960, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1631379173}

author: {'steamid': '76561198146984766', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1564029695}
review:
4/10 - Serviceable, but sloppily done and mediocre tower defense game with a retro vibe and many serious problems. Full review below.

=Intro=

So I thought I'd played pretty much every tower defense game on Steam. Then I found this one.

=Gameplay=

It's a bog standard TD game with a few twists. Resources are gained by mining minerals rather than killing enemies and enemies can also attack your towers if they get in the way, or the AI feels like it.

The 'titans' (black squid like critters) will spawn from their designated area and make a beeline for your command center. You build turrets and defenses to stop them. Heard this one before?

After each level, you can upgrade your turrets via research, unlocking more powerful turrets, defenses and utility structures, such as ones that speed up mining and ones that empower nearby turrets.

Defenses come in a solid variety, and I like the control over how your aresenal grows - although it's far too easy to completely gimp yourself by researching useless crap.

The game's biggest failings are it's sheer lack of information provided. What exactly does this research do? Why didn't you tell me that rocket launcher would destroy my own turrets? What does this building do again? Tooltips are poorly written and even simple mechanics like when monsters spawn, how money carries over from level to level and what specific creatures do are either barely or never mentioned.

Aside from this, the game tries to do a sort of persistent campaign, with some cash transferring from level to level. However, it also aggressively auto-scales the difficulty based on your money, meaning you can inadvertently make things extremely hard for yourself by dint of...doing well in the previous level.

Ugh. I love the idea of a persistent TD world, but this is the wrong way to do it. There is no persistence, only ways to make life harder for yourself without knowing it.

On top of this, towers feel both wimpy and clunky - it can be hard to judge how big a tower is and where it can be placed in advance, leading to frustration and even the bigger and more powerful towers, with a few exceptions, feel weak both in terms of visuals and damage.

Finally, the controls are a bucket of butts. As towers will build wherever your cursor is, it's far to easy to accidentely place an extra utility structure or turret somewhere useless - and since only 50% of the price is refunded, this can neccessitate a level restart. On top of this, when (trust me, it will happen) you respec your research tree, every new research item brings up a screen that will automatically take you to the next level, unless you back out and then re-select it. Odd...and rather sloppy design.

=Graphics and Audio= 

Graphics are retro as heck, with scanlines and screen artifacts lending everything a sort of 1970s B-movie look. However guns look...mediocre for the most part, enemies are all slight variations of 'black squid' and it all looks really same-y after a while.

Audio is okay, but again - nothing memorable and starts to grate soon, in particular the sound effect for an alien dying or attacking your turret. I quickly muted it.

=Style=

Some neat ideas here, but not packaged especially well. Again, I like the idea of a semi-persistent TD game, but this is the wrong way to go about it.

=Value=

Quite a few levels to get through, medals to own and the obligatory Endless mode too. There is also a sandbox/level editor. However...the game just isn't good enough overall to justify a purchase outside of a deep sale.

=Overall=
+ Some clever ideas
+ Distinct visual style
+ Deep research tree

- Very little information provided on essential mechanics
- Research feels 90% useless 
- Weird, counterintuitive difficulty scaling
- Irritating music and audio effects
- Clunky control system

At the end of the day, you can get better tower defense games even at this price point. Defender's Quest and Gemcraft are both far superior titles. If you've played both of these, this may be worth a buy, otherwise - wait for a sale if you are interested.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039086242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1364713200}
review:
The known Puppygames stlye combined with tower defense, not a boring game that is for sure.
Mobs do not run on a rail while you shoot them down, they can deviate and will to chew on your defenses or to avoid them.

But, it has a few flaws that makes me not like this game that much: 

First, Many of the info is not displayed and you have to figure them out. Detailed tooltips would have been nice.

But more important is the other hidden feature: difficulty is auto scaling based on with how much cash you finished the previous map. Coupled with the fact that you need to conserve money as some of it caries over means the difficulty spirals out of whack quite quickly. Which in the end punishes you for playing well. If I want a bigger challenge I will crank the difficulty up myself, I do not need the game auto do it for me, thank you!

author: {'steamid': '76561197982180153', 'num_games_owned': 2960, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1375932608}
review:
Mi sono sempre scordato di recensire questo gioco, ma ora ne approfitto perchÃ© lo sviluppatore chiede soldi su Patreon per realizzare il seguito, e vi prego di non darglieli.

Questo gioco ha richiesto un lungo sviluppo e lo sviluppatore ci ha messo l'anima, solo che Ã¨ molto testardo e non ha mai ascoltato le critiche degli utenti, ed il risultato si vede.

RotT Ã¨ un gioco difficile perchÃ© mal fatto, pieno di scelte errate di design.
Sebbene tecnicamente sia ben fatto, queste strane decisioni di design lo rendono estremamente frustrante, rendendo necessario ricominciare d'accapo la campagna fino a che non avrete capito come lo sviluppatore vuole che giochiate ogni singolo livello, quale dei mille upgrade dovete acquistare e quando.
Un'ottima recensione che spiega nei dettagli quanto Ã¨ fatto male questo gioco la potete trovare qui: https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198027104941/recommended/93200/ (se conoscete l'inglese, e guardate anche quanti voti positivi ha ricevuto).

Dopo essere stato bombardato di critiche e di richieste di supporto perchÃ© il gioco spesso non si avviava nemmeno, tale sviluppatore ha anche scritto un lungo sfogo nel suo sito, nel quale, in pratica, dava la colpa a questi utenti e non si assumeva nessuna responsabilitÃ .
In realtÃ , i problemi tecnici sono stati sempre dovuti alla sua pessima scelta del linguaggio di programmazione (Java), e sempre alla sua scelta di utilizzare la versione installata nel sistema per far girare i suoi giochi (che hanno tutti avuto questi problemi).
In pratica serviva installare Java per far girare i suoi giochi, ma ovviamente poi, per i soliti problemi di sicurezza che hanno sempre reso questo linguaggio la pessima scelta che ancora Ã¨, bisognava aggiornarlo ogni volta che usciva un aggiornamento, il che al tempo accadeva spesso. Il "bello", Ã¨ che ad ogni aggiornamento, gli sviluppatori di Java cambiavano cose che rendevano quasi ogni versione incompatibile con quelle precedenti, rendendo alcuni software inutilizzabili fino a che i produttori non rilasciavano un aggiornamento per supportare la nuova versione di Java.
E cosÃ¬ anche i giochi di PuppyGames smettevano di funzionare, e lo sviluppatore (che probabilmente non aggiornava mai la sua installazione di Java) veniva bombardato di richieste di supporto tecnico.
Alla fine ha imparato come si usa questo linguaggio ed ha incluso nei suoi giochi una completa installazione locale di Java, come facevano tutti gli sviluppatori di software Java da decenni. In pratica, nella directory dei giochi, ora sono inclusi tutti i file di Java necessari per farli girare, senza utilizzare la versione installata nel sistema.

Anche per quanto riguarda la giocabilitÃ  tutti i problemi sono dovuti allo stesso sviluppatore, perchÃ©, come ho detto, non ha mai ascoltato la parte della comunitÃ  critica ma solo coloro che gli facevano i complimenti, e pertanto il risultato non poteva che essere ciÃ² che Ã¨: un gioco bello da vedere ma pessimo da giocare, che il genere vi piaccia oppure no.
Il voto medio su Steam Ã¨ dovuto al fatto che molte delle persone a cui questo gioco non va, lo hanno semplicemente ignorato, oppure recensito negativamente al tempo dell'uscita, e per qualche ragione ci sono molti giocatori che preferiscono i giochi da imparare a memoria piuttosto che quelli che richiedono qualche abilitÃ , perchÃ© imparare come terminare un livello di RotT non richiede nessuna strategia ma solo memoria, e questo E' un gioco strategico...o almeno dovrebbe esserlo.

Ora PuppyGames chiede di dargli dei soldi per realizzarne un seguito.
A parte il fatto che questo modo di fare le cose non mi Ã¨ mai piaciuto (chiedere soldi alla gente per realizzare qualcosa...perchÃ© non fai come tutti e chiedi un prestito o un finanziamento?), ma in questo caso specifico, finchÃ© non avrÃ² la certezza che abbia cominciato ad ascoltare la comunitÃ  di giocatori, non supporterÃ² mai piÃ¹ questo sviluppatore.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967223692', 'num_games_owned': 913, 'num_reviews': 223, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1537576235}
review: I don't understand how this game has such a high rating, I can't stand playing it. As someone who has been playing Tower Defense games since Starcraft custom games, and RTS games even longer than that, I am not having any fun at all with this 'hybrid.' The pixel graphics are awful. That can usually be ignored when they are charming or unique, but that isn't the case. They actually make it harder to play. The gameplay isn't fun at all, and the progression and level system is terrible. I have to assume people are upvoting this out of some kind of nostalgia, or loyalty to the people that made it due to them making other, better games. The fact that you cannot tell if your walls or towers are properly placed where you want them, that enemies enter from every side of the map, and that it very often becomes an insane cluster of pixels on the map, has me giving this a negative review.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999459739', 'num_games_owned': 1112, 'num_reviews': 545, 'playtime_forever': 64, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1549756593}

author: {'steamid': '76561197985236447', 'num_games_owned': 892, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1546042251}
review: Pretty solid Tower D game that came out during a time when there was a big push for games of this type. Played it for quite a while when it was included in one of the very first Humble Bundles as a beta and poke back in on it now and again. Since that craze has died down, I think this is a very servicable TD game with a nice look to it, but for me, after some years, it just doesn't quite have that hook. If you're a fan of the genre, I recommend it because you can usually get it for a fairly decent price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035643926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1545888784}
review:
I dislike the swarm style TD -- for this game enemies don't follow a path, and most times will actively move AROUND your static defenses (how is that even tower defense? :P).  

Although the tech tree is impressive, it doesn't allow for the 'choose your own gameplay style'. If you don't configure a tech tree specific to the enemies of that map you're about to play on, victory is impossible at the higher dificulty levels. 

The scale of battles is also underwhelming for the swarm style - to the point where I found myself with a lot of resources to spend on static defense, but no space to meaningfully placing them. 

Overall, if you could handle these issues, you will enjoy this game at a discounted price.  If any of these issues bother you from hearing of them, you may not enjoy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983968524', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1094, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1671196869}

Better play some really good TD like Kingdom Rush etc.

P.S. This game isnt fun at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990026208', 'num_games_owned': 423, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 653, 'last_played': 1473767836}
review:
Fantastic little game. If you enjoy a bit of Tower Defense here and there, with some rewarding progression to top it all off; this game is for you!

Art style is pleasing to look at, levels are fast paced and nail-bitingly intense. Although it might not look like much on the surface, there is a lot of fun to be had for $14.99. I crushed a number of hours both in the Humble Bundle AND Steam versions of this game, and have enjoyed every minute.

Overall, TD lovers are going to have a blast. Great casual passtime!

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197971470922', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1533995836}
review:
As a point of reference: Huge fan of Defense Grid here and tower defenses in general.

pros:
- I love the graphic style. i think this is done right
- Sound is nice. That base that kicks in near the end of a wave. Gives you chills!

cons:
- too many upgrades, you get lost in them. Right from the start
- Not big difference in turret styles, I am still unsure what the heavy blasters did vs normal blaster. Their look/effect/sound/rate were too similar..
- Hard to place building. Really.. the grid is not clear, and you will endup with gaps and screw up your placement
- hard to distinguish different type of aliens
- Area of effect upgrades don't do much as far as I can tell. They should literally double the speed of the turret. Otherwise there's no point.

Could have been more pros/cons if I played more. But I just couldn't get into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999413547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1533891310}
review:
Overall good indie game. A few problems:

1. Building/strategy is hectic. Too busy trying to plop buildings down, it's more a game of speed and dealing with frustration/stress than a thoughtful strategic game.
2. Too many multiplier type buildings. So you are pressured to just build stuff ASAP before it gets destroyed, yet there are all these complex mathematical multiplier buildings you need to put down and connect (specifically for ore gathering).
3. Money/ecomony mechanics unclear. It's just throwing buildings down randomly and making a good defensive line each time. Get's boring, only able to put in a few minutes a day.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996025816', 'num_games_owned': 317, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 86400}
review:
This game is punishing. Most tower defense games, each level is like a puzzle you have to figure out. Make a mistake, and you can restart the level and try a different strategy. Revenge of the Titans instead requires a whole-game strategy, with a massive tech tree that carries over from level to level. If you don't invest in the proper technology each and every time, you will eventually be thrust into an unwinnable scenario. You can't simply restart the level, you have to restart the entire game.

Unless you love trial and error gameplay, or games that require the use of a guide to complete, avoid this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060548361', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1533725917}
review: This game is well made and really nice graphics and sound. The problem? It feels too barebones at times. Maybe I did not play the game long enough to get into the details, but I did not enjoy the beginning enough to reach that point. The initial turrets are dull. I do not know how many Titans are going to come in a wave (which is probably intentional), I do not know where they will walk on the map or if they will break my building (again probably intentional). In short, I had to repeat several dull initial stages which I would rather not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021271675', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1530752084}
review:
Tower Defense game, creeps come from general directions but don't follow linear paths which makes tower placement and layering a little more interesting.

Money holds over from each wave so the less you spend each round, the more you extract each round, the more money you'll have going forward to start the next round with. I really enjoyed that aspect.

R&D has lots of depth and allows various strategies to be explored. 

Overall I'm excited to play the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198014638690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1661808959}
review: This game ... Where do I start?  It's had me captivated since I first tried it out.  I can't say how this game compares to other "tower defense" games in terms of difficulty, but this one drags me in and smacks me around.  I've found myself trying run after run to see what strategies are more successful than others.  From the music, the atmosphere, the style; this is a glorious  title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016723761', 'num_games_owned': 478, 'num_reviews': 179, 'playtime_forever': 661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1530118563}
review:
[h1]Good, but not what I expected[/h1]
[list]
[*]It's not a pure TD, there are no lanes thus the titans will attack your towers. You also have an economy to manage (crystal harvesting RTS style).

[*]DIfficulty is adjusting based on how well you are doing, making the game very challenging. You can turn that off in the options or even try the easy campaign. Either way, the game is a tough nut to crack. As a testament to this, according to global achievements only 1.5% have beaten the final campaign boss (50 missions). That's concerning...

[*]The art is great, as is the humour - music is generic though.

[*]Large enough tech tree that you can reset whenever you like and try different things/towers/combos. That said, I ran the same setup for the last 20 missions.
[/list]

Overall, it's a thumbs up since I sinked quite a few hours in the game (some offline). Also the developer is frankly amazing, you can see him answering every thread at community discussions even after all these years. Cheers!

[table]
 [tr]
  [td]Gameplay[/td]
  [td]6/10[/td]
 [/tr]
 [tr]
  [td]Aesthetic & GFX[/td]
  [td]8/10[/td]
 [/tr]
 [tr]
  [td]Music & SFX[/td]
  [td]5/10[/td]
 [/tr]
 [tr]
  [td]Time Played[/td]
  [td]15hrs[/td]
 [/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Final Score: 6/10[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197977709487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 481, 'last_played': 1529064972}
review:
This one has been sitting in the back log for years from an old sale.
This game throws monsters at you with no guide to how you should set up your defense. Place your center of gravity in one area, and the enemy will walk through a different path. Every few levels a boss monster will appear, and instead of avoiding your center of gravity, will destroy it. You get powerups (though you have to get to them and click them before they dissapear) like extended range or quicker reload, and items, like bombs and shields  that carry over through levels. Best off saving them until boss levels.
Well worth $5, but no more. I got exactly 8 hours of entertainment, and a good challenge that was -almost- addictive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008282906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 285, 'playtime_forever': 943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1534732042}
review:
Check out my Steam Curator page, "Minorthreatt Gaming Reviews." I have the most organized and extensive genre lists on Steam! Be sure to "FOLLOW" for more of my recommendations: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31339849-Minorthreatt-Gaming-Reviews/?appid=257170

The Short of it: The ultimate mash-up of Real-time Strategy and Tower Defense! The art style really grabbed me, and then the gameplay rang true to back it up. A true mash-up of genres, and it works. Chaotic tactical!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994925125', 'num_games_owned': 152, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1573109734}
review: I installed the game and it was in a window so I chose Full screen. In Full Screen too much of the game around the edge cant be seen so I can't play the game. I tried to reinstall thinking that it would come back in a window. It again came back unplayable. So this Steam subscriber is not a happy camper.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963358821', 'num_games_owned': 1021, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 2072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2072, 'last_played': 1523837795}
review:
One of the best tower defense games.  I'm not a big fan of tower defense, but this I will play.  There's a sort of beauty in the way you can either paint towers like it's ms paint, or lay them down precisiely.  The music and sound is great.   I like the atmosphere and the scenario.  You're essentially fighting a war for the survival of mankind,  pushing back alien forces that have consumed earth, back to their base.  A little remiscient of Ender's game.  

There were a few times in the campaign where I got completely stuck.  I ended up having to completely change my strategy and some of the really tough wins were very close, and felt like I only won them by luck.  Mostly wins require strategy and skill, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017681447', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1662256502}
review: You get what it says on the tin a nice little tower defence game. Purchased this after playing some other 'Puppy Games' purely because I like the sense of humour within the game and they are nicely done and easy to get into if you want to waste a few minutes, problem is I end up playing it for hours. This is a nice game and worth a try, thumbs up!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970671483', 'num_games_owned': 632, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 2290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2177, 'last_played': 1665110820}
review: Super fun and stylized Tower Defence Game with perfect progression speed and variety along with spooky sense of urgency. Punishing in just the right ways it is worth it full price to Tower Defense fans and on sale to those looking for a cool little sci-fi game. Thumbs up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198051889459', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1657075483}
review: i love it

author: {'steamid': '76561198263427469', 'num_games_owned': 442, 'num_reviews': 246, 'playtime_forever': 832, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 832, 'last_played': 1521186022}
review:
A nice concept but bad implementation.

RotT was released long time ago when there weren't good TD games in Steam excpet Defense Grid. I think it's the reason why this game has such a high rating. I found this game very boring and tedious.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1331893863

Aliens attack Earth. You need to build up defenses to protect humanity. After that you invade aliens homeworld. 

This game is a mix of RTS and TD genres. You have the command center which you must protect. Enemies come from everywhere. You can build refineries to gather resources and place towers. 

It's like a usual RTS game but you don't make units but towers. Could be really nice, but it is not.
First campaign contains 10 levels. All these levels looks like the same, I have got only 2 towers (actually 1 tower and better version of it) and 3 enemies (alien, big alien, bigger alien). It was like I played same level 10 times. Almost nothing changes.

Do you think second campaign is better? No... i have got totally new tower only at 16 mission. Yeah, missions are short but anyway. it's not fun. Also I played on hard and I am sure i could beat then by playing only 1 toe.

Between missions you make research which unlocks new stuff. And it's the best part of the game.  It's cool. But it's not enough to make the game good, because it's not the main gameplay.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1331893963

Pros
- Nice concept and design
- Interesting Tech tree
- Cool visual effects
- Funny texts

Cons
- Boring main gameplay
- Similar levels
- Too easy

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1331893913

[h1]Resume[/h1]
I found this game extremely boring. There are a lot of levels but they play like the same. I can't recommend it

author: {'steamid': '76561197970880630', 'num_games_owned': 1060, 'num_reviews': 417, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1518902489}
review:
Hesitant to give this a positive review, but, will do so if you can find the game for a few dollars. 

Basically it's one of the first tower defense games I recall pirating, played it again a few years later in 2018 and while it's got that retro 8 bit awesomeness down pat, you have zero idea on the pathing of the Titans so no idea where to actually build.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088429378', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1389403545}
review: If you follow me you know I love tower defense games.  However this one just didn't do it for me. The animation was decent, reminded me of old video games or cartoons.  But I couldn't get into how it worked for some reason, and I'm very sorry I can't better identify why, to help them (or others) make better games.  There is nothing in the game that stood out as "bad" to me but it just wasn't for me I guess.  Perhaps it felt to kidish? Dunno.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031525163', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 376, 'last_played': 1516647661}
review:
Revenge of the Titans es un divertido Tower Defense con una soprendente direcciÃ³n artÃ­stica, que por desgracia en mi opiniÃ³n no acaba de dar 100% en el clavo.

Sus mejor baza es su impresionante acabado grÃ¡fico, muy pulido y detallado. Supongo que no es para todos los gustos, pero para mÃ­ es uno de los mejores ejemplos de su clase (no sÃ© como catalogar el estilo xD)

La mÃºsica cumple junto con los efectos. Nada que destacar especialmente.

El juego dispone de una campaÃ±a normal/difÃ­cil (leer mÃ¡s abajo), una campaÃ±a mÃ¡s sencilla, un modo desafÃ­o, un modo supervivencia y un modo de creaciÃ³n. Si la propuesta del juego te gusta, hay chicha para rato.

Este es un juego que empecÃ© con gusto pero que he terminado teniendo una opiniÃ³n infoerior del mismo al finalizar su campaÃ±a principal, por cuatro motivos principalmente:

- Para ser un Tower Defense con gestiÃ³n de recursos, llega a ser demasiado frenÃ©tico. Poniendo como ejemplo el reciente "They are Billions", hecho de menos la posibilidad de parar el tiempo para poder preparar mejor mis defensas. 
Uno puede acabarse la campaÃ±a de forma menos Ã³ptima sin problemas, colocando las torretas en rutas de colisiÃ³n con los Titanes, por ejemplo, pero si quieres ser econÃ³mico, quirÃºrjico o elegante, en ocasiones el ritmo del juego no te dejarÃ¡.

- Los recursos que consigas en un mapa serÃ¡n los que tengas disponibles para el siguiente. Esto genera situaciones bastante extraÃ±as, en las que tienes misiones en las que nadas en la abundancia para encontrarte inmediatamente despuÃ©s con solamente 2/3 de los recursos iniciales.
No niego que la culpa pueda ser mÃ­a por menospreciar el aspecto de recolecciÃ³n, pero dependiendo de la misiÃ³n (los mapas son aleatorios) recolectar puede hacerse un poco complicado, o simplemente no necesitas hacerlo de forma tan acuciante porque claro, ya tenÃ­as recursos de sobra al comenzar... No me parece una mecÃ¡nica del todo clara ni bien explicada.

- La dificultad aumenta de forma exponencial. La campaÃ±a posee una duraciÃ³n aceptable, con una o dos decenas de misiones divididas en cinco planetas. Lo que ocurre es que de uno a otro la dificultad pega unos saltos que parece que falta un planeta entre medias para ajustar.

- Existe un Ã¡rbol de mejoras que vamos desbloqueando misiÃ³n a misiÃ³n, pero no todas las opciones que nos dan son igual de buenas o Ãºtiles. Tres de las seis torretas bÃ¡sicas son prÃ¡cticamente opcionales, ya que consumen una gran cantidad de recursos desbloquearlas que podemos usar en opciones mucho mÃ¡s Ã³ptimas. 
Al comenzar la campaÃ±a da una falsa sensaciÃ³n de libertad y adaptaciÃ³n, pero en la prÃ¡ctica creo que algunas opciones no son tan interesantes.

En definitiva, Revenge of the Titans es un juego aceptable, que sirve para pasar un rato entretenido si te apetece un Tower Defense con algo mÃ¡s de chicha. Es un tÃ­tulo al que he vuelto en un par de ocasiones y lo volverÃ© a jugar en el futuro, porque tiene un encanto que (casi) hace perdonar sus puntos flojos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038327570', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1514843355}
review:
Got in a Bundle. Way better TD games exist.
I edited this review as I am not recommending, not from a lack of understanding of how to play a TD (nothing new about this genre), I don't care for this game and am not recommending it. Not gonna go back and play it again just to write a more 'sophisicated' review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052007123', 'num_games_owned': 6823, 'num_reviews': 1307, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1515019259}
review: Revenge of the Titans is not a bad game, but it's a huge mix of everything and nothing - lots of action and "strategy". I don't get if this game should be so easy, but you don't have to plan anything at all. There is no challenge in this game, just put random towers (even the first one will do) at/near spawns, harvest everything on map and that's all. Something got past your "defense"? Just drop tons of cheapest towers at enemies and they will be crushed. Froze time on boss fights and boom, around 2-3 hours later you just beat the game. This game have interesting graphics, effects, but the music and sounds were more of pain than pleasure. Sadly, if I wouldn't finish this in one sitting, I wouldn't probably run it again. Also, I wouldn't even call this game a Tower Defense. It just doesn't feel like one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961692031', 'num_games_owned': 183, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1511986429}
review:
I cannot recommend this game. 

You never feel in control of the situation. There is no way to tell where the enemy will approach. No matter where you set up your defenses, the enemy will either move around to avoid them, or destroy them in the blink of an eye. And you never have enough resources to cover all possible approach paths. So in each level you just try to hectically put down towers where they're needed. The game tells you "don't build in the titans path", right but if you don't the towers are out of range...not to mention the enemies that run right past your towers without so much as a "how do you do"...

Just not fun to play. If you want a good RTS game with towers, get Creeper World 3 instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962368812', 'num_games_owned': 696, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1511238451}
review:
It has some enjoyable aspects, and a fun kitschy asthetic but a number of design decisions have made me bounce off the game without enjoying it multiple times, to the point I've given in on extracting the fun out of it now.

The biggest gripe being the adaptive difficulty setting and funds that persist through across the campaign. It frustratingly makes efficient, tactical play unsustainable, since the next level will require you to spend more than the extra money you saved in the last level to overcome the powerful difficulty spike. The best strategy is to waste just the right amount of money each level to keep the difficulty on an even, managable keel; rather than have a sudden difficulty spike and lose almost everything for the level after. The mechanics of the whole thing are completely obscured so it just takes trial and error and some luck to find the sweet spot of "finish level 12 with $xxxxx to actually enjoy level 13", because it really doesn't happen naturally. I'll admit I'm not a fan of these kinds of mechanical slight of hand designs in general, but when they're restricted to helping people who struggle on a certain level or hit a bad spot of RNG rolls, it feels relatively inoffensive. Here though, it's crushingly heavy handed and outright annoying in the way it swings the difficulty around unevenly. Especially so when there's even an option cryptically labeled "no auto-adjusting difficulty" which only turns off the "help-you-if-you're-stuck" aspect of the system whilst leaving the "screw-you-for-doing-too-well" aspects locked in.

Speaking of cryptic: The UI's rather obscructive, there's a number of buildings and upgrades that simply don't give you enough information. There's an augmenting building for resource collection that just says "faster" with no indication of if its going to be cost effective to build one on that level without some more trial and error. Likewise the whole robotics line of buildings gives you no idea of the damage potential of what you're investing in. And on the flip side, a number of researches give you a global bonus to something, and tell you, but you only find out about it after you purchase it, there's no way to plan for it without, yet again, some trial and error.

It's a little clunky too. The briefings and unlock information all come up in painfully slow-moving letter by letter text, and clicking to speed it up just skips the information entirely rather than print everything out at once on click 1 and skip on click 2, so you either have to twiddle your thumbs waiting to read, or skip the information entirely. You also have to navigate the map in-mission with WASD or mouse dragging, with no-minimap functionality and a playable area that's 2-12 screens wide is a chore that seems like it could have been easily avoidable. And god help you if you try to drag the view too quickly after exiting build mode, you'll just burn on your money on a useless line of defences instead of moving. 

The building footprints are clearly grid based, but there's no visual indication of the grid itself to make things easier to line up, not even a footprint for the building you're currently trying to place even though a large number have rather unintuitive footprints compared to the sprites. Because of the booster modules, efficient defences are frequently tightly packed clusters, but the grid being small and invisible makes it very easy to accidentally offset things by 1 and ruin the bonus-sharing pattern. You can freehand draw a line of buildings by clicking and dragging, but there's no option for a proper straight-line drag building, even though mostly you want everything aligned. Enemy paths are seemingly semi-randomly generated at level/campaign start and not telegraphed in any way even though they don't seem to follow any hard and fast rules. So the clunky build controls are especially vexing when you have to build defences reactively based on precisely which random path they take, rather than planning pre-emptively.

Overall, no, not recommended. It's charming enough on the surface, but the gameplay actively fights against your enjoyment in some instances and refuses to make even commonplace quality of life concessions for player sanity in others. The whole affair feels like an unsatisfying session of chasing moving goalposts. There's plenty of other good TD games out there, ones that feel like they value your time and enjoyment much more highly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067499373', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1510079350}
review:
I don't recommend this game if you are more like a causal player, or don't want to study extra material, how to play it. It has strategic qualities, but either there is a lot of issues in design, or I miss a lot of information and don't even know I should search them on the internet or possibly in some manual.
The game is not simple tower defense game, the invaders don't strictly follow the road in maps. They take shortcuts and can destroy easily your structures alongside or even take a different path to attack them. On the other hand they don't have really an A.I., so they still follow more or less the path. And they disappear, when they attack, except for "bosses".
So you build more like forts than plop buildings alongside marked path.
But there the first issue comes: It is not clear, how the buildings will fit. Since the graphics is simple, I would maybe appreciate see the lines of squares, where can I build and what space the new building takes, when I am building. Right now I often ended up with finding out that that space I left between the previous building and rocks, is not enough for any other building. And selling the building does not return you full investments. This is very frustrating to find out that it is better to start playing the map again and perhaps do the similar mistake with other buildings at some other place.
Then the graphics is simple, but not enough symbolic sometimes. Some buildings look very similar (and strange to my opinion, not nice).
But there are visual effects of big explosions or when being attacked. Your screen can shake sometimes or blurâ€¦ This is not helping in crisis.
Sometimes you hear or see some kind of explosion, but you donâ€™t know, what has happened. It can be alien destroying some items on the map, which are probably just a decorations.
But sometimes few your buildings near to the missile tower explode and there was no invader next to them, so I wonder, if there is some random accident rate on hard difficultyâ€¦ Or if it was a bugâ€¦ In the end it seemed better to not use missile towers.
You might have a feeling that the default high difficulty is very easy, until you get further on and find out that you did not earn enough money in previous maps and should replay them. The money, you start with, is taken from previous map in the campaign!
You cannot zoom out, so some maps are very large and hard to orientate when there are hordes of enemies already flowing.
Maybe part of the issues above could be explained by some manual or forums. The game has not real tutorial in the campaign, but more like hints to let you start playing immediately. So I did not have reason to search for manual etc. I think I will rather get to Kingdom Rush or similar tower defense games, they are more causal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081536193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1509443729}
review: Great art style. Good gameplay. Terrible tower defense game. No waves, just barrage of eneimes (sometime with a boss). All are coming at you at the same time at the start of the level. The amount of your starting money depends on how many turret you lost on the last level. So you could lose everything if you fuck up. Why are there so many options for upgrades when 90% of them are useless? The only good turrets will only be the first four. Everything else are too dam expensive to build within the time given. Even when the refinery is fully upgraded, its still useless without building dozen of them. By the time you have money to build something cool, the wave is finished. Now this only applies to the shitty story mode. at least sand box mode was entertaining for an hour.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998809331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1704853071}
review:
I didnt know about the difficulty rising with the earnings you make until i read a review below mentioning it.
This game was high on my tower defense list but its just dropped quite a bit because of that.
Like what the fucks the point of working hard to get more money to make later levels easier for yourself if its only gonna raise the difficulty to make what you spent that money on pointless.
I still like it and hopefully the extra difficulty ties into scoring on the leader board to make up for it but someone else will have to answer that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995433131', 'num_games_owned': 465, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1413275522}
review:
Edit: So, I've been told that this game shouldn't be viewed as a TD game, which I can understand in a way, maybe it should be viewed as a "strategy of some kind" kind of game... However, it's clealry tagged as a TD, and is viewed & reviewed as such, so my own review will remain the same since I bought is as a TD. Maybe if you're looking for a quirky strategy game, this could be for you... anyways:

Edit 2: My review was reported/blocked for a long while  by a dev (and I also got banned from the forums... still am, according to what it says) because... uhh... well I guess they didn't like my review even though it's... well, you know... a review... So, yeah, I'll have to recommend this even less now that the devs (or someone working for that company) have shown themselves to be so vindictive and petty against someone who paid for their game and happened to hate it (which as far as I know, I'm allowed to)... so yeah, screw this.

This is such a bad TD game that my biggest regret is I can't permanently delete this abomination from my library without deleting other actually good games because I got it in a Steam bundle many moons ago.

It's SO bad, that I'm actually thinking about deleting the whole bundle and re-buying the others just so I can never look at it again. Yeah, that bad.

It does have a couple of good things I guess, the visual style is, or at least was, intriguing when it came out (now there's a ton of dime-a-dozen "retro" pixel art games everywhere), and it kinda looks like an interesting game...

However, it's not. It's a VERY subpar TD, with shody mechanics, and beffudling upgrade system and don't even get me started into the whole "difficulty being tied to the economy" issue. That's one of the single most stupid game design decisions I've seen in any game, let alone a TD game.

Hell, I even tried just cheating to see if it would be enjoyable that way... guess what? Nope, it was still a frickin' drag to play, so as an avid TD afficionado, I'd say: Stay away from this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050152150', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2224, 'last_played': 1499377285}
review:
The fatal explosions never once did fail to send a deafening pulse through the soldiers ears. The battlefield was a deathly arena with gun-fire and the smell of rotting corpses left with a war-cry face on them. The smoke obscured the enemy trenches in the distance, a strange aggressive language spouted out, but became quiet as they were granted an eternal rest. Coffee will full every machine gun, tower and building, even science runs on coffee, the SCIENCE of WAR, in this revenge of the titans, I dont really know what the Titans dude to earth before, but at some times this "war", this game just feels like slaughter and sometimes you are on the winning side, other times you are on the bloody dying side... One of the most authoritarian general I have ever seen is in this game and the most strange Scientist, after all he run on Coffee... Its a tower defense with Huge Titan Killers that give you a huge, HUGE pleasure in killing, I can still hear the sund of the plasma hitting their face,
Muahahahaha, hitting his face!! DIE TITAN!

review:
Not for people looking to breeze through with 100% completion.
Game can be a little rough, normally does not warn you until it is too late.
But I think that adds to part of the replayability if you like the game.

There is so much research you could play through a half dozen times before you unlocked everything.
