author: {'steamid': '76561198046747192', 'num_games_owned': 493, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1601845258}
review:
Its a base building Tower Defense which lets you spawn factories that produce vehicles which automatically seek out opponents.

Its quite tough and the well working strategies are hidden, you should read them up in a guide.

Offers a techtree which adds replayability and random levels. I think you can also create your own levels but never looked into it.

I like it but as said its quite tough. The graphical style of it is really cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136557457', 'num_games_owned': 149, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1515631336}
review:
El juego trata sobre una invasiÃ³n alienÃ­gena, nosotros los humanos debemos defendernos de los titanes y monstruos espaciales que vinieron a comerse nuestras ciudades, nuestra base principal es el objetivo de ellos a destruir en cada mapa, es un juego de defensa de torre. 
Seremos invadidos a medida que el juego avance por diferentes categorÃ­as de enemigos y de diferentes lugares, tendremos que saber administrar nuestras defensas acorde al enemigo por donde viene o a las caracterÃ­sticas del mapa.
En resumen el juego es muy bueno, entretenido podes pasarte hs de juego, dinÃ¡mico no tarda en cargar, toque grafico estilo pixel. 
Existen cupones de descuento para este juego y asÃ­ vale la pena adquirirlo. Lo recomiendo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023666926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1772, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 519, 'last_played': 1489799310}
review:
I like tower defenses games but in this game some parts ruining this for me. First some positives I love visuals of this game and amount of upgrades but there are lots of things I don't like. Upgrades are not very well designed, first of all you need upgrade one part of technology to upgrade another bot often you ended up looking from one icon to another and compare to see what you need do first to make another step closer to thing you want to do, tree based upgrade system would solve this in no time. Another thing is that you don't have enough information what upgrade give you, some give you only option to upgrade another items but some give you +1 damage, armor or something like that but you din't know it until you actually get this upgrade and get some more information with this.
Gameplay- well this is not classic tower defense, you can place tower anywhere and enemies also coming from general directions of pointer not exact point and can walk freely. not on specific path, so this make it harder to make strategic decisions and you have to react quickly to what is happening on map and you don't have active pause to do so. Camera shakes, glitches and other visuals effects sometimes make chaos on screen and I turned it off quite quickly. You can zoom out and in bigger maps this would be very, very helpful to see better situation on battlefield especially when you can pause and move to different parts of map.  Another thing is adaptive difficulty setting and transferring money from one level to another, this is interesting, in theory sound good but in real life scenario not always work as should, if you do good in one level your reward will be that next one will be harder, sometimes much harder than it should be. And money transfer from one level to another can cause that in next level you will have barely any money if you do exceptional bad in last one but still finished it.
And lastly after some time it all feel the same, levels are generated randomly but due its random nature and way you can place towers and how enemies can walk freely it feel very similar and repetitive. Ans there are some more tings I can complain but I think this is enough to decide if this is game for you or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044081373', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1590201683}
review:
A casual approach to the tower defense genre. I've played the crap out of the Humble Store release of Revenge of the Titans, and continue to enjoy it. 

For those who find tower defense games a bit too tedius, Revenge of the Titans may just be your bag. Mission layouts are simple. Units are simplified and easy to manage. Upgrades are comprehensive and fun to experiment with. Enemy units are easy to figure out and fun to battle. All-in-all, Revenge of the Titans gives tower defense newbies a decent handle on the genre's mechanics.

Tower defense veterans will probably be put off Revenge of the Titans simplified approach. However, every gaming genre needs a quality title with a low barrier to entry. For the tower defense genre, Revenge of the Titans is precisely that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043786030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 718, 'last_played': 1440388443}
review:
The highest-average-rated game in the original three indie bundles a few years ago, I believe.  It's fun, diverse, and employs a variety of old-school tower-defense features which can keep a casual player goofing for hours.

After the difficulty-cap begins to level off due to poor-leveling, the game can become tedious for me.  The levels player over and over again, with no immediate solution in site.  Often times the last thirty seconds of a won match can boil down to liquidating player towers like their walls, so various amounts of destruction ensues.

For it's price, it's perfect.  It's a thumbs up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048101201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 200, 'playtime_forever': 631, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1482969605}
review:
Revenge of the Titans has excellent art design, is really challenging, and the towers and units have a pretty solid feel to them in gameplay and animation terms. It took me a long time to get around to finishing it due to the fact that the campaign used to allow you to corner yourself in a bad part of the tech tree, but this has since been patched out. What's left is a game that's suitably challenging and open-ended to be quite fun - for the most part.

Of the complaints worth mentioning, some of the levels are so dark that even with my screen brightness turned all the way up I can barely read the terrain. It's also not always clear which objects block construction or obstruct the firing arc of which turrets (but to be safe, assume almost all objects block your turrets from firing).

My biggest problem, though, is with ghostly enemy types that can only be attacked by manually using a Capacitator turret against them. This rips you away from the high-level strategic game into click-driven micro instead, and I think that really interrupts what is otherwise an exciting and challenging high-level planning experience, much to the game's detriment. If the ghost/capacitator system wasn't a part of the game, you'd have a much more cohesive experience overall that really lets you get into the flow of things.

That said, it's still a good game, one of the most engaging tower defense games I've ever played. Give it a shot and just keep your eyes on those damned capacitators (which, incidentally, are a good way of defeating bosses).

author: {'steamid': '76561197989254794', 'num_games_owned': 608, 'num_reviews': 428, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1525135985}
review: It goes without saying that defence games such as this aren't much to write home about but this would be the exception, as far as a $10 game goes at any rate. Varius modes and a campaign carry it as any, with a ludicrous research system as you face ever-greater hordes of titans. The theme and sheer variety of what you can toss onto the field are what make this one stand out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996097280', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1679, 'last_played': 1353484800}
review:
An excellent RTS - Tower Defense flavored game.

It's been a while since I played it through on STEAM
however - what I do recall is the campaign and the humor was quite fun

but after completing the campaign
I kind of got lost in further post-campaign missions
that allow for more in-game progression

It was a little difficult to keep track of what thing I had completed
and what thing I wanted to go do next.

Yet - besides that
all gameplay, music, humor, visual style, etc. really worked for me.

I rate this:
4 out of 5 cups of coffee     :-)

author: {'steamid': '76561197984431371', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1480391792}
review:
Very pretty, with a variety of enemies and an interesting and large research tree, but ultimately ruined due to poor balance and bad gameplay decisions by the developers.

At it's core, it's tower defense with funds and research carried between levels. You can replay old levels in order to improve your funds or undo research choices...but going back is permanent, losing your progress after that level. Essentially this makes the game about creating a single, perfect, optimized run...which most people would find incredibly tedious anyway, assuming the gameplay was interesting enough to support constant replays - which it isn't. At the very least, you'll be replaying every level at least twice: once to learn what you're up against and where everything spawns, plus at least one run to beat it with minimal losses. This gets tedious real quick.

The big problem with this is that the game *also* penalizes doing well. Difficulty scales to your funds (= how well you've done so far), and it's not a minor correction, either; monsters get significantly harder (up 3x life and speed) and more numerous and crystals ($) actually stop spawning at all after a certain point. That's ridiculous, and what's more it doesn't go back down unless you lose the game repeatedly and let the monsters wreck your base. In a game whose mechanics practically mandate replaying levels in order to get perfection, this is ENRAGING.

There are plenty of other problematic design decisions (extremely large damage ranges for some weapons, easier difficulty requiring losing to access, lack of a sandbox mode, most Research being useless, etc.), but this is the big one. Ultimately, the game encourages you to play one way, and when you do, it punishes you for it.

I don't write reviews very often. I want to like this one so bad, and I've gone back to it repeatedly...but not once have I had fun with it for more than a few minutes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971490143', 'num_games_owned': 1321, 'num_reviews': 226, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1479247331}
review:
I really wanted to like this game. I love the art style. I love tower defense. But this game doesn't work for me. It's hard to pinpoint why, but somehow the game fails to drag me in. There is no controlled progression. Why this might be cool for advanced players, it isn't for new players. After the first couple of missions there is no help from the game. It seems that you can completely mess up the research tree since there are so few pointers of what to do.
The levels feel very random. Aliens come from all kinds of directions and typically follow the road, but now and then they don't and it is impossible to plan for this unless you know that. So gameplay boils down to a lot of trial and error, which doesn't work for me in most games. I prefer tower defense games where I get a new level and then try to figure out a solution from the knowledge gained in previous levels. This is impossible here. There doesn't seem to be any information of how the waves look like. Special enemies are not introduced well. And on the battlefield it is also very hard to distinguish all the different kinds of enemies, because while they have specific differences, most of them look very similar. And everything is very chaotic and hard to follow.
So, in the end you put down a couple of buildings and hope for the best. If you place them in the wrong spaces. you'd better start over.

I did play for a couple of hours and then looked on Steam for opinions on the game because it felt like I was missing something. And a lot of reviews confirmed my impressions. But I also had to learn that the game needs you to respec your tech tree depending on the level, which simply doesn't feel like a good game design decision.

The game might be fine for people who like chaotic tower defense games without lanes and less strategy and more reactive tactics. But be prepared to retry levels over and over without even knowing how to improve your setup.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009474246', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 1363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1363, 'last_played': 1478125178}
review:
Hard,  but not annoyingly hqard jugglefest that is general tower defense game 'difficulty',  the challenge in this one is figuring out the best way to set up your defenses and not just what spot you should lay a turret  down so the enemies will backtrack around it. 

I prefer more casual play myself but this game  gave me a lot of enjoyment. 

Get it on sale if ya can as there seems to be no working level editor anymore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026124098', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 1118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1088, 'last_played': 1474481829}
review:
This Tower Defence with a plot, based on an alien, and how to defend was intriguing, and at the same time one of the most challenging tower defence games that I have played. Once I started playing I just could not stop until I had done everything that I could in the game. From the unique talent tree, to killing all the giant titans that they could throw at me.

The last level was especially challenging and took quite a few attempts to get it right. The diversity of towers is great, from the hard hitting rocket tower (which if you not careful, destroys your own buildings), to the straight shot laser tower. I found that a strategy that worked for me in the early game, no longer was an option as the game went on, and found myself morphing my stategy into a new one, that I would never have guessed I would use. The campaign was good fun, and was a bit easier to play after tinkering in the endless mode, just because you managed to try all the towers. The campaign had a mini boss to each world, which came back during the later levels. The cash roll over system (the cash you have at the end of the level is what you start with at the next level), was a challenge at times, but the game scales the level difficulty according to how much cash you have. As you progress, you find combinations and ways to save cash. (More cash, higher difficulty). Was a great way to keep the game going even if you had a bad level.

If you don't want to have any tips or hints that I found useful, stop reading now! (spoiler)

If I can give a tip to anyone who wants to play this game, never underestimate the power of the Capacitor. Learn to play it well, as you will find out how much it helps. On a side note, you are able to get the holiday achievements by changing the date to the 24 December, and this part I found really incredibly hard. Having to balance having limited towers, but also the balance between attack and farming made it even more challenging.

ABSOLUTELY LOVED THE GAME!

author: {'steamid': '76561198179342283', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 253, 'playtime_forever': 1270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 518, 'last_played': 1635683123}
review:
TOO HARD, TOO RANDOM!!!!!

Edit:
I tryed to give it a second chance, but i puked. This is not even a game! So much randomness! It's trial and error. Enemies just go around your buildings or attack them, randomly. Stages have random enemy types. When you win, you win by luck! Upgrades are useless. Most of techs (upgrades) are there to unlock other techs. No planing required - strongest turret wins. Huge levels WITHOUT a minimap!!!! You like to scroll, from left to right, from right to left? Yes, you do! Everybody likes to scroll, especialy when something explodes somewhere! You never build in the middle of the level, because the paths of enemies are unpredictable. So you try to block them where they spawn, but they just go around you, through the black edge of the level. So you build closer to the edge, so you can't even see who or what spawns. This is fun, isn't it!?

Edit 2:
OK, I tried it a third time. I thought "pride aside, let's do it on easy mode"... and it turns out, it's even harden then the normal mode! On easy, you have easier levels, but less minerals, so you get less income, so you can afford less, so you die even earlier, because all the enemies stay the same! Fuck this game! :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198153962279', 'num_games_owned': 8332, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1472864444}
review:
[h1]What Is Revenge of the Titans?[/h1]

Puppygames is a developer that I genuinely respect & appreciate because they intimately understand how to properly design & create vintage arcade-era retro-games on modern gaming platforms, in a way that is both immensely satisfying & true to form. In fact, they are one of the very few studios who do such games justice in my opinion because their sprite-based pixels feel innately alive and demonstrate a phenomenal sense of immersion for 2D graphics, brimming with a magnetic energy that pulls you right in and won't let go. 

Within their catalog on Steam, they currently offer 4 wonderful titles to choose from which are all highly acclaimed gems, whereby each shares a common style & aesthetic but features differing gameplay mechanics derived from their arcade counterparts. And these include: Titan Attacks, Ultratron, Droid Assault, and Revenge of the Titans - the latter of which shall be the focus of this review. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The Titans to be found here are your arch enemy from the sky, and these morbid monsters with their brightly glowing eyes have returned once more to Earth hell-bent on finishing up the job they started: destroying your prized bases. And there's so very many of them, myriads of waves in fact...marching toward you relentlessly in unison. That's because Revenge of the Titans caters specifically to tower defense fans, whereupon you have the ability to strategically build up a counter-attack in real-time using various clickr emplacements such as blaster turrets, explosives, battledroids, barricades, mines, and tangleweb...to name but just a few...each type offering its individual strengths and weaknesses which must be taken into account when choosing which is most optimal to use, as well as where it should be placed for maximum effectiveness. 

You'll have a finite amount of money to spend at any given time, and you will be purchasing these defenses and/or upgrades for them via an in-game economy...with collected funds being derived from nearby mining operations which you must set up and tend to continually so as to replenish your ability to engage in more purchases as needed to help stave off these enemies. 

Rest assured that the gameplay is indeed rather challenging...yet also with a refreshing level of depth to it...necessitating the ability to think fast on your feet in order to achieve maximum success. There is a tremendous element of tactical planning involved, especially when considering the wide array of different resource types available at your disposal in the bottom section of the screen.  

And with a whopping 50 levels to overcome in the campaign alone, plus 5 different gameplay modes (standard campaign / easy campaign / endless / survival / sandbox user created content)...it is clear that countless hours of fun are to be found here without it ever becoming too monotonous in any way. I was certainly excited to reach the next successive wave after being awarded various goodies from the last, no matter how many I previously played. There's always new usable items and rewards being unlocked as you progress further in, which is a rather nice touch in facilitating a sense of progress being made the whole way through.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

You'll find that the bright vivid colours contrast beautifully against the black background in their games, and this one is no exception. Furthermore, you have the ability to drag the larger gameplay area around the screen so as to focus on certain sections of it as needed, which is a nice advantage to have...both in planning as well as combat. Additionally, there exists an optional shader effect which can be enabled, adding monitor scanlines plus a distortion effect...thus emulating the look and feel of an old-style arcade monitor so as to increase the sense of immersion. Personally, I was quite content to play without it though, but it's more a personal preference and allowing the user to choose their own is ideal.

[h1]Audio[/h1]

We all know how larger-than-life sound effects are such an integral aspect to these kinds of games, and in this one I'm delighted to report that you'll experience the most surreal auditory sensations. The electronic soundtrack as well as the synth it uses are simply sublime, hypnotizing you with its distinctive melody, while the thunderous explosions of these Titans being annhilated by your defenses will be sure to impress. Puppygames have got this down to a science - it's a definite hallmark of their titles.

[h1]Steamified?[/h1]

It fully is, and includes both trading cards and many achievments to be unlocked.

[h1]Verdict - 9/10[/h1]

As somebody who isn't even a die-hard fanatic of tower-defense type games, I was quite drawn in to this one nonetheless because of who it was made by. I knew it would be presented in a way that was both accessible and user-friendly (especially with the way in which it gradually teaches you the ropes as you go along via an in-game tutorial), while at the same time making me feel like I was playing the cousin game to Space Invaders (ie. Titan Attacks). It all exists in the same universe, and so after having completed that one already, it was only natural for me to try my hand at Revenge of the Titans as a follow-up experience. And I felt right at home instantly, soon mesmerized by the pew-pew sounds and complete obliteration of my foes. And the best part of all is that I had quite a fun time with it as expected...fully appreciating the robust strategy side to its gameplay, and even more, the allure of its premium presentation. 

I'll rate this one a 9/10

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

- Wide assortment of defenses
- Delightful synth soundtrack
- Superb art style
- Steam achievements + trading cards
- Online Leaderboards

[h1]Cons:[/h1]

- Monster paths can be difficult to gauge, a bit of guessing involved
- Not a big fan of garbled voice effects in general
 
For similar reviews and great giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com

review:
Revenge of the Titans ist ein gutes Tower Defense Spiel von einem kleinem Entwicklerstudio

Die Titanen wollen die Erde erobern und du bist dazu aufgerufen worden, mit neuester Abwehrtechnologie die Erde und spÃ¤ter auch 2 andere Planeten zu verteidigen.Titanen, die deinen StÃ¼tzpunkt zerstÃ¶ren wollen sind hier an der Tagesordnung.   

Zuerst hast du nur
eine kleine Auswahl an TÃ¼rmen und GebÃ¤uden und damit dir nicht langweilig wird SpezialgegenstÃ¤nde die du nach jeder Runde weiter ausbaust.(SpezialgegenstÃ¤nde werden von Titanen fallen gelassen oder erscheinen auf deiner Karte). Zum erforschen dient dir ein hÃ¼bsch sortierter Forschungsbaum der dir jede Runde die Frage stellt: was erforsche ich jetzt? Damit dir das aber nicht zu viel wird, hilft dir nach jeder Runde ein qualifizierter Kriesenplanungsmitarbeiter und gibt dir nÃ¼tzliche Tipps, was du als nÃ¤chstes erforschen solltest.

Aber damit ist es noch nicht alles: verschiedene Modi wie: Ãœberleben und Endlosmodus sind auch 
noch im Spiel verpackt.


Alles in allem ein durchaus  gutes Tower Defense Spiel, das seine 10 Euro wert ist. ; )

review: I became aggressively addicted to this game until the final round or so - I couldn't figure out a way to beat it and I gave up.  I can honestly say I really loved playing this.  I loved the soundtrack, I loved the art, I just felt that it was a very polished tower defense game.  I am glad I gave it a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013317980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1602830490}
review:
Revenge of the Titans is a really well done tower defense game. There are a vast amount of options for play. There are user created maps and campaigns as well as several included campaigns and modes.  The gameplay is tower defense but the enemies donâ€™t follow a predetermined path but will wander. You also have freedom of placement of your towers, so there are many ways to set up your defences. 

One of the things that I like about this game above other T/DF games are the RTS elements. There are resources to gather and upgrades to get. The upgrades are more towers, unit spawners, and support buildings.  Itâ€™s really a lot of fun.  Itâ€™s not complicated or very deep but I donâ€™t believe thatâ€™s the point.  This is very much a game (in the sense that itâ€™s main goal of the game is to just be fun, nothing serious at all).  Most of â€˜Puppygamesâ€™ games are lighthearted in tone and pretension.  I respect them for making genuinely fun games. Give this game a shot, itâ€™s a lot of fun and well worth your time and money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013017981', 'num_games_owned': 788, 'num_reviews': 518, 'playtime_forever': 784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1462916592}
review:
Un tower defense con algunos toques diferentes, tanto como si arbol de progresion como sus efectos de "panel de control" y que de los que se unieron al a nueva idea de que los enemigos tambien ataquen a tus defensas en vez de llenar una linea con centinelas lv 5.

Aunque si tiene sus puntos buenos el juego no lo recomiendo por lo sigiente

El dinero que ganas de la anterior mision despues es el de la sigiente, asi que por esto si no administras bien (que es un 
poco raro que pase) podes o no tener nada o una fortuna y poder poner todo lo que quieras

Los poderes son limitados, hay que saberlos usar

Es muy rapido todo, pones tus maquinas para hacer recursos sentris tus barrincadas y aceleras el tiempo hasta ganar o mejorar si esta mal

Arbol de mejoras un poco aburrido y confuso, tambien que las cosas sin desbloquear no te dicen que hacen muy bien, ni sus estadisticas


No es tan malo, es mediano pero si me tengo que inclinar le a un si o no, doy un negativo

author: {'steamid': '76561197969619765', 'num_games_owned': 341, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1459152368}
review: I've played all manner of tower defense games and Revenge of the Titans has quickly become my favorite. Instead of placing all enemies on predictable rails, the developers let the baddies attack from all sides and all directions. The art direction is supreme and the difficult curve is set just right. I'm still trying to figure out exactly how / when / why to upgrade certain technologies, but there's no penalty for depth in a genre that usually lacks substance.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970602587', 'num_games_owned': 6364, 'num_reviews': 3660, 'playtime_forever': 515, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 515, 'last_played': 1453783683}
review:
https://youtu.be/ceC5y74MrdM

The Titans have been a real pain in the butt if they aren't attacking they are revenging.  This time the humans are taking the tower defense route to solve the problem of the titans.

Build offensive turrets buff them with technology while defending your base and resource gathering buildings.  Between each round research new tech to keep up with the ever stronger waves of foes.

The game oozes style and has a good sprinkling of humor, however the core gameplay falls short.  To make it to the end of the campaign be prepared to repeat levels over and over to optimize your play.  If the gameplay lived up to the style this would be one of the best tower defense games out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971060812', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1592855301}

author: {'steamid': '76561197996844285', 'num_games_owned': 269, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1237, 'last_played': 1498103964}
review:
Absolutely phenominal simple tower game. Very easy at first, and becomes VERY challenging. No matter who you are. The game adjusts the difficulty of each missions based on your performance so far.

Huge tree to unlock tons of different towers. Great amount of enemies. Good number of different objectives to keep things spicy. 

Overall a great TD game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020554800', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 138, 'last_played': 1451583394}

author: {'steamid': '76561198063465895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 461, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1451987445}
review:
Puppygames games are excellent, and Revenge of the Titans is not an exception. Responsive, accurate, visually amazing, and with variant choice and adaptive difficulty. My complains are very few and far between:

My one problem with the visuals is the effect for an enemy hitting your base. It REALLY hurts my eyes when the main base is hit, and the entire game jiggles about like a fat person on a trampoline. It'd be brilliant if this could be reduced or turned off.

The titan AI seems a little... erratic. The game doesn't have enemies on a preset path exactly, so when i place my turrets out of the way, enemies will sometimes still walk over to them and destroy them. While this isn't exacly a PROBLEM, it's still something I wasn't a fan of.

Other than that, the game is amazing, and you should definately buy it. And every other Puppygames Game

author: {'steamid': '76561197983514500', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1578205766}
review:
The game is a tower defense with a ton of customization. Really cool to look forward to all the stuff you get to use. And fun to try out different strategies. But it gets really unfair. You need more money to beat the hordes of enemies in the later levels. But the more money you have, the harder it gets. Add that on top of the difficulty ramp up and its like the game is punishing you for playing it. It gets to the point were you have to restart the level over and over until you have something manageable.

In short, do I regret playing it? no. But if the game was more balanced it could've been amazing. Its just sad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005566455', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1683038878}
review: This game is punishing not hard, the enemies are unpredictable and when things go to hell you're not mad at yourself for doing something wrong. The game just throws a lot of bullshit your way without you being able to defend yourself against it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024730417', 'num_games_owned': 463, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 3086, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1140, 'last_played': 1458895374}
review:
Tower defense games seem to come in two sorts these days: those where stages are played like an RTS from an overhead view and those where you get down into the trenches FPS-style. Revenge of the titans is by far my favorite game in the former category. This is because the range of options it provides, and the incentives it offers to explore them, make it much more centered on creative design than anything else in the genre I've yet played.

Titans works essentially like every other tower defense game: set up defenses around something, a wave of baddies swoops in to destroy that something, you must manage your defenses in real time until the stage is complete. But Revenge also has some features which differentiate it. The pixel-art graphics are charming, though they can be a bit confusing in the thick of battle. If you've played anything else by Puppy Games you'll know what I mean as this style is their trademark. Personally, I think it another great strength of the game, though it may not be everyoneâ€™s cup of tea.

The stages are very large and very open. The defenses you construct are not bound by a grid, and will likely consist of many, many components rather than just a handful of parts. The size also adds to the challenge: enemies enter the map from many different points in a single stage and are can be difficult to coral. 

All this gives you a considerable amount of freedom in coming up with a defensive plan. Many towers interact, so you will be designing and placing installations with scores of interrelated parts, not just putting up some towers on established paths. 

Complementing that freedom is a component of management and upgrading. There are two aspects to this: first, there is a deep upgrade tree which, over time, grants you access to new and better towers. This provides a variety of weapons and defenses, but also forces the player to choose which to ultimately prioritize meaning that by game's end you can have very different sets of advanced tools at your disposal. Second, the resources you use to build must be procured during stages via mining, and your balance caries over from level to level. (Thus, in typical PuppyGames fashion, how you play in one stage carries over into subsequent stages.) The fact that your starting resources for the next stage are what remains from the last makes the game into a campaign, and provides an added incentive to devise elegant defense solutions which conserve resources. 

Both of these features can mean that itâ€™s possible to get into a situation where a stage simply isnâ€™t feasible due to your prior decisions and mistakes. Conveniently, you can return to any prior stage at any time and play forward again, so your decisions are only as set-in-stone as you want them to be. I found that this actually created replayability, as I went back to try and conduct a better campaign. On the other hand, there were a few points where I found I needed technologies in ways I couldnâ€™t anticipate and had to backtrack to get them.

To sum up, Revenge of the Titans is a tower defense game that gives you space to invent and a reason to do it. If you like the traditional tower defense genre and also enjoy the sort of creative design typical to good sim games there are hours of fun for you in Revenge of the Titans.

review: Very unique tower defence variant with a very pleasant artstyle (puppy games). You also need to manage recources like minerals and can upgrade your stuff while in campaign mode. Still the fact that the enemies attack your defences for no reason and forcing you to constantly rebuild adds to much pressure and takes away too much fun for my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999932264', 'num_games_owned': 1233, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 86400}
review:
When this game came out you could only respec by going back and replaying several levels back... for instance, if I needed a particular tower for a level but I was off in the research tree by three points I had to go back three levels to respec for the tower I needed to beat that level, only to find out that choice would not allow me to have a tower I needed for the next level making it impossible to continue wihout going back and picking another tree all over again.

I put up with this a while, but it became so frustrating I quit, as did my buddy who picked up the game at the same time.

Since then they patched in the ability to change what you've researched and respec at any time. Too late, I already hate this game and the people who made it. If you came along afterwards you may not understand how I feel or why, and you may very well get some enjoyment out of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034500962', 'num_games_owned': 404, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1523839122}
review:
This game is incredibly difficult, which I've noticed is why a lot of people don't enjoy it. While it is frustrating, it's the same kind of frustration caused by games like 'Super Meat Boy'. I can guarantee, fans of 'SMB' (aka masochists) would love this game simply for the replayability and difficulty curve, and I think that's the major issue. This game's targeted demographic is tower defense players, but 'Revenge of the Titans' follows almost none of the normal tropes of tower defense games like 'Bloons Tower Defense 5' (a well polished browser tower defense). 'Revenge of the Titans' I believe suits fans of games with heavy replayability and difficulty, better than the average tower defense player. Now, that isn't to say other tower defense games aren't hard, they just aren't difficult *in the same way* as 'Revenge of the Titans'. 'RoT' requires a much more significant amount of spacial planning and strategy due to the "open" nature of the map and undefined enemy waves. There is also a good deal of micromanaging in collecting powerups and bonus money while simultaneously keeping an eye on your turrets, buff towers, and factories, whereas in lots of other tower defense games (like BTD5), you usually just place your towers and then sit back while the wave finishes itself, and this I think is the most important difference between RoT and other tower defenses; *the amount of attention required by the player at any given moment.*


TL;DR While many of the defining qualities of 'Revenge of the Titans' is a huge turn off for casual and/or average tower defense players, it is these qualities that make 'RoT' such a fantastic game for people that enjoy heavy replayability in tandem with masochistic amounts of challenge, and who don't like to sit around waiting for a game to finish its "autopilot" to do something again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116558380', 'num_games_owned': 4484, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1439012349}
review:
The game look's fun, but this is not the best tower defense game.
The art and effects look's good and different from others, but an open map where monsters can avoid your turrents and go after your base, that's no good.
If you want to buy it do on a sale because it's not worth the full price, the difficult increases to fast, the passives, and skill tree looks good but they are all meaningless, there's no point on upgrading a tower, the enesmies rush you very fast, your towers are destroyed to easy.
The game is so fast phased that each round will alst 1~2 minutes, and you will not even research 1/4 of the skill tree before you end the missions.
But probably you will just get bored after a while.

overall: The game is fine but there's better tower defense's and its not worth the price, this game needed much more polishment to be worth the full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985969658', 'num_games_owned': 999, 'num_reviews': 685, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1434213420}
review:
Nope. Very low budget looking, which I could be fine with, if everything else worked. Every level looks the exact same, as it is some brown terrain with your base at the end and then guys coming from off the screen. First off, there is no enemy variety, they all look and function the same, strike 1. Then there is the fact that the spawn points make no sense and they will be all over the place meaning you have to defend a ton of different sides, making your defense weak at every point, strike 2. Then, in a tower defense, their pathing SUCKS. They don't follow the actual paths, they just kind of randomly run at your base and spread out all over. Oh and don't forget they will attack your base, and the game tells you not to build it in their path, but then makes them have inconsistent pathing. This means no matter where you build your tower they will run at it and attack it and you will always lose your towers, strike 3. Then there is the fact that your towers have TINY range and won't attack them about until they are getting attack themselves. This also means you can't put towers behind each other or they won't attack the enemies, strike 4.

 Then there is the fact you cannot maze at all, because if you put up walls they just attack them instead of try to get around, strike 5. Then there is the progression system. Each level you get 1 unlockable. Problem is, they are usually wasted. If you want a new tower, you need to get like 3 unlocks, meaning for 3 levels you waste your unlocks, and during those 3 levels you don't progress or get stronger at all, which can be a problem/ The other unlocks, don't give you a good enough idea what you get or the effectiveness, strike 6. You will get things like collectors to boost refineries or cooldowns to boost towers, meaning you have to spend points researching them, then during the game you have to spend tons of money buying them, just to boost your towers, instead of just researching tower boosting stats, which actually makes sense. Also, the boosting towers you don't get a good idea how much they help, strike 7. In game scrolling over towers doesn't give stats, just shows sell prices or name, not letting you make informed decisions, strike 8. Then there is the fact that at certain points you will be unable to beat the level based on the way you specced. So you need to respec and keep using trial and error to get the right combo, meaning you actuall have little choice as you can't win with different combos, strike 9. I do like the mustache captain that talks though. Needless to say, after so many strikes and missing every part of what a TD game is, this game is OUT. 5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026485814', 'num_games_owned': 1275, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1433859771}
review: Generally, a principle feature of tower defense games is that the enemies stay on paths so that you have to think about where to place your structures.  In this game, enemies just swarm you and setting up is a matter of guesswork, which throws out any strategy besides "put down lots of guns and hope it works".   What really didn't help was the voices of the characters that popped up after every mission and research project.  Listening to their "BLUH BLUH BLAH BLUH" was like a mosquito cheese grating my ear canal and quickly killed any drive I had to keep playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041944840', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1431876382}
review: Revenge of the Titans makes for a good mix of RTS and Tower Defense but certain aspects of the game hold it back. The game starts out simply enough with it's simple/geometric art style and ease of game play. But the difficulty ramps up in later levels and you will be punished for mistakes you made in earlier levels. The amount of money you have to use in each level is rolled over to the next. So if you let many of your buildings get destroyed, they will not be recycled and that money will be gone even though you won the level. Adding to the difficulty, upgrades to the tech tree are necessary but you don't really know how much they help you until you use them which requires a lot of practice and trial and error. Many buildings you use early on in the game also prove to be less effective or even useless in later levels. You will need stronger, more expensive guns but you will not have the money to purchase them because you were not careful in the earlier levels. Do not be deceived by the cute graphics! I breezed through the early levels but then felt like I had missed some very important strategy when I got to the later levels. But by then it was too late and I did not want to back track and replay all the early levels. This may be heaven for a hardcore strategy fan but, personally, I found it too frustrating and chaotic in the later levels to be enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009671381', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 316, 'playtime_forever': 1267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1267, 'last_played': 1417268681}
review: Nice tower defence game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061519611', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 3930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3930, 'last_played': 1426820626}
review:
I think too many people get this expecting a tower defense game - when it is actually more an RTS. After the introductory missions the enemies do not strictly follow a path and will actively move to avoid your defenses, so you can either turtle by your base, try to control the choke points, camp the spawn points or a combination of the approaches. 

Your resources (money) carries from level to level so if you are doing bad the later levels will be more rough. But saying that, most people don't realize the AI is adaptive so if your money is low the levels will be easier (and vise versa) - actually funny to read how some players cheated and gave themselves tons of money only to find that they could not kill the enemies because the difficulty was jacked up so much. Therefore, if you play within reason, I think the game always gives off a decent difficulty vibe.

One negative I would agree with the others about is the lack of instructions - it can be daunting to figure out how to deal with the new enemy types but I think that as long as you have armor piercing turrets most of the rest is manageable. As a pro-tip, the laser with all the upgrades is overpowered and will help you out immensely. Also consider looking at some youtube videos on later levels to learn how to properly turtle - I think that it is the most effective approach in the end-game when enemies will rush you from 9-10 spawn points and evade defenses.

Overall, I played this game for ~65 hours and got all of the achievements and I think it is pretty great hybrid TD/RTS game. I recommend giving it a shot if you are a fan of either genres. 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198041248860', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1382033782}
review: Great potential, design is bad. Only redeeming feature is the artstyle (and the only reason I bought the game). The game just gets way too hard, way too quickly and doesn't follow any of the Tower Defense Genre norms (eg. balanced skill tree, preperation time before waves, and countless other basic faults.) The game was fun while it lasted (on the earth levels) but once I hit the moon sh1t turned hard, and bloody quick too. The game can be fixed easily but you are probably better off going to MiniClip and play the Monkey/Baloon Defense game. P.S. The game didnt get hard due to lack of skill, you just had to know what comes in the level before you even get there! I ended up just placing mines in a line as my main form of defence.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994971635', 'num_games_owned': 341, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1429159702}
review:
Tower defence, quaint voxel style art, and a whole lot of upgrades that do nothing.

Each level lasts about a minute, depending on if you respecced into the right upgrades or not.  There's not really any placement strategy, as the monsters just kinda wander from where they spawn towards your base.  There are tons of upgrades that you unlock one at a time, and you can respec before any given level to change up your weaponry.  Once you find the right combo of upgrades that actually do anything you basically stick with that for every level after that until the game throws a wildcard at you and you need to respec the entire tree.

That said...  Theres nothing particularly bad about this game.  Everything works as it should.  The design is all there, but theres nothing particularly great about any of it.

I don't dislike it, I just don't reccomend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002985447', 'num_games_owned': 2288, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1387948303}
review:
I don't care whether you like tower defence or not, whether you loath it with every fibre of your being. BUY THIS GAME. AND THE SOUNDTRACK. If all you get out of it is the soundtrack, you've come out ahead.

The game itself is good, but listening to the soundtrack for the first time outside of the game my knees went weak. It's phenomanally good, and should be a lesson to people on how to chiptune, how to re-interpret famous classical music, and how to choose music for your soundtrack.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976663594', 'num_games_owned': 279, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1428782330}
review: The thing that sets this game apart from other tower defense games is the fact that matches last 1-2 mins and take place on open ground. If you've played tower defense games before, you already understand that it's not a very good idea. And, indeed, it doesn't work out, despite a few nice touches here and there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089056721', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1460295520}
review:
Revenge of the Titans is a really good game. It is challenging yet addictive. With over 5+ planets you can explore (each increasing in difficulty), you can always replay the game. If you do not like your skill tree, there is a neat little Refund button to reset your skill tree. (Don't worry you keep your points XD). Although it lacks in story, it is a neat little game which I strongly suggeest everyone plays :)

-Le Overlord

author: {'steamid': '76561197969228435', 'num_games_owned': 991, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1423775266}
review: This game looked cool to me because I like tower defense games. About 2 hours into the game I can't motivate myself to continue. There is no real challenge and the upgrade system seems meaningless. This game is not totally bad but it feels very mediocre to me. With so many more polished and fun tower defense games on Steam, there is no real incentive to play this. Definitely not worth the full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995186433', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 5483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5312, 'last_played': 1524659181}
review:
While i agree with the amount of people saying that the "Difficulty rises too quickly" and that the game "Punishes you for spending all of your money in one mission by making you broke in the next"...

(Oh and there will be S.P.O.I.L.E.R.S in this review, so theres a warning)

I can't deny that this game has some very fantastic mechanics, the art style is just AMAZING for one, the tech tree brings variety into the game, will you fight your enemies with explosive rocket launchers that can damage your turrets, or will you go full god like and have powerful blasters behind them with buildings that increase their range, damage, ammo capacity, firing speed and decrease reload time. Or maybe you just think "I can do SO much better!" well, sadly you can't have a tower that shoots, but you DO get a tower that SHOCKS the titans as they come into range with a click of the mouse, and add multiple ones together, and you got yourself a FORCEFIELD that will kill anything on your command!

But maybe you don't wanna see towers shoot the titans from far away, maybe you wanna send DRONES in that get up close AAAAND personal, starting with tiny droids that mass produce very quickly and shoot faster than the basic blaster (Puts that blaster to SHAME), then going to BIGGER droids with bigger guns that act like a TANK for the tiny droids, but thats not all, upgrade the droids so the tiny ones have a better weapon and the bigger droids? OH boy lets say they get a WHOLE new weapon (Im not gonna spoil it, but lets say this weapon is DEADLY against anything really that doesn't have armor)

With 5 planets to battle on (Earth, Moon, Mars, Saturn and Titan), the fighting never stops until you defeat the final boss on every planet leading to titan, each planet holds a new variety of titans, earth has your standard titans, moon moves onto armored titans that might force the blasters blasts to be defencless, so you gotta get better ones, mars has ghost titans that are unnoticable by regular blasters (Unless you get that certain upgrade that allows that to happen), so you must use the special shock towers to kill 'em, saturn has FLYING titans that will drop bombs on your towers, crazy isn't it? Titan however, has titans that will SHOOT your turrets from afar, as if titans dropping bombs from above wasn't bad enough, titans shooting your towers with armor will be your biggest problem.

Again, the dificulty IS harsh, i mean this game will full on throw EVERYTHING at you every new level and the game kinda says "Ok, so you got this thing, kill it, ok? Ok, have fun with that" each new level, to a certain degree where it feels like its screaming "HEY BTW WE GOT THIS NEW THING THAT YOUR TOTALLY GONNA HATE! HAVE FUN!" all the way to the last level where it just says "Well you know we can't be bothered to google the definition of mercy but were pretty sure it means you need to prepare yourself (before you rek yourself)"

Yes i PROMISE there will be rage-quits, this game isn't exactly all easy otherwise i'd rather not review this game at all.

I top my hat off to puppygames for creating a game that has variety and really pumps some love into a genre that i consider dead now (and tower defence games are my favourite :> )

HOWEVER, i have to give 1 VERY big problem i have...

And that is, there is a bug within the game that puppydog games just either flat out refuse to fix (on purpose) or just try to avoid it, seriously i mentioned this problem twice on the steam forums and all i got is halfway to knowing whats going on then...nothing else, and this problem is only apparent on steam apparently...

[EDIT] BUT- The developer has managed to find a loophole with the steam cloud being disabled, while this 'problem' occurs if you have steam cloud enabled, just disable it and it'll work like a charm!

WATCH A GAMEPLAY VIDEO I DID ON THIS GAME HERE: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jQR7l5Sg5TQ

author: {'steamid': '76561198039494538', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1425466257}
review:
Interesting game with great humour and style and more character than most TD's out there.

NOTE: Ignore all the negative feedback about not having enough build time at the start - you can take as long as you want and you'll only be attacked once you place a refinery down. The game place by default is very slow as well so you have plenty of time to place towers after the attack starts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030937547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1562721759}
review:
Ugh. Sometimes I hate the simple yes/no type of voting. If we're doing it that way I have to recomend this game, but truth is it gets way too hard way too fast and becomes frustrating.

It's fairly standard tower defense. But there's a huge twist in that what you research and the money you collect on one level carries over to the next. So you must be extremely frugal in the early levels to have a shot at winning the later ones. If you didn't do that great say 5 levels ago that can snowball so quickly into a huge defeat later and you won't see it coming and have no recourse but to restart 5 levels back. It kinda sucks.

But the retro styling is very cool and it's solid gameplay, although some research options need more explanation. Also super annoying is the stats for the guns are displayed when you first research them but not again later. The tooltips could be a lot better. I'd give this game 3/5 stars, not great, but fun and cheap when on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017200784', 'num_games_owned': 853, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1377135216}
review:
Fun sci-fi tower defence

The story is somewhat simple. Basically, aliens (titans) are invading earth and it's your job to stop them. 

Gameplay revolves around classical tower defence cliche's with sum bonuses. Basically there is one campaign to play and you unlock levels as you win them. The aim is to protect your factory from being destroyed. You have a limited number of towers you can place on the field, in order to defend your factory (which has limited health). When your factory is destroyed you immeditely lose the game. As you win each level, the money you earned gets tranfered to the next level. Furthermore, as you progress though the story you earn points which you can use to buy new towers, walls and other buildings. There are a variety of towers available including lasers, plasma, support anti- air. All towers will have limited ammo and will have to spend time to recharge again. Towers may be upgraded when clicking on them and spending resources (ie. money). You collect money by building resource gathering buildings. there are a wide variety of enemies including (strong-weak) land and air units. In some levels you will be facing a boss which requires clever placement of towers to destroy. You can aslo call upon limited abilities to assist in the defence such as bombs and fire-rate boost. defeated enemies may drop money or abilities to use later. The game lasted me 12,7 hours so it's decently long, plus you can replay levels after you beat them.

Audio serves the game well. Weapon fire sounds vary between lazers and other weapons. The sounds also help invoke a strong sci-fi, yet cartoony feel to the game (ie. less serious), Other sounds such as alarms are clear and crisp to help warn you of attacks at your base. Dialogue is spoken through text boxes only and there is no audio. 

There is also a survival mode besides the campaign which tests how long you can last. 

If your looking for a good tower defence game get this NOW!

author: {'steamid': '76561198003037363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 774, 'last_played': 1422908043}
review: This game is a polished masterpiece in the tower defence genre. Its addictive fun and beautiful. My goal is to get every achievment possible!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006135085', 'num_games_owned': 222, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 1508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1508, 'last_played': 1422073693}
review:
It's tough to recommend this game unless you really REALLY like tower defense games.

Going through my backlog of games, I started playing Revenge of the Titans which I got from a Humble Bundle years ago. At first, it was kind of neat. The art style was simple and kind of cool, the music was decent (in the end levels in particular, there's this really good ambient track), there was a little bit of humour in the campaign, and it seemed like there would be a lot of variation in enemies and weapons as you level up. But several hours in and the gameplay flaws really began to show.

- There are maybe 3 very distinct enemy types. There are tons of enemies in this game, but they pretty much vary only by things like "oh, this guy moves faster" or "oh, this guy has more armor" etc. 
 - Level after level, the grind shows itself. Same gameplay, pretty much every single level. (Other than when you need to use the Capacitor, a specific weapon used for a specific enemy type.) There's never any variation, or anything that makes you scratch your head and plan something out. And the art of each level pretty much varies only by colour.
- There's loads of weapons and gadgets to unlock and use, but you'll most likely end up using the same combination of weapons for every single level once available.
- Campaign is started on the hardest setting by default...and it's mind numbingly easy.

Most of my play time was spent grinding for the last few achievements (which was honestly the one thing that kept me going.) So, I'd give it a 4.5/10. It is a decent game for being so cheap (especially from a Humble Bundle) but again, only if you are desparately wanting some sort of RTS/TD game can I give a full recommendation. The developers also seem really nice too, and are active on the discussion forums, which is a plus.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008452744', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1421630228}
review: If you're really into tower defense games, this is definitely one to check out. This one's a little more on the hardcore end of the tower defense spectrum I think, pretty chaotic with enemies coming from a lot of directions, and the build/upgrade tree is challenging to grasp at first. The ZX Spectrum robot is a fun retro throwback for those across the pond, but it's too bad that the sandbox mode is a paid DLC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108642150', 'num_games_owned': 697, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1478746411}
review:
This is a great game to waste time with, beautiful graphic style, and fun. Perfect mix of retro and modern. It is a bit faster paced than most tower defense games but that is one of the best parts. It is not boring after 10 minutes or more. I don't like tower defense games that allow you to pause and take your time to plan moves, I would rather have to learn to make faster decisions on the fly. I am a bit biased as I happen to like all Puppygames. I have played this game on my another computer and had to finally purchase a copy for myself on Steam. Also if you have a retail copy puppygames will send you a steam key if you want to play on Steam. Most other company's wont do that for their customers,  if you want to play a game you bought from them on Steam you will have to buy another copy on Steam, like Epic Games.

There is a learning cure but not too long and the visuals are great, also like all Puppygames there is some great audio. A fun game that wont put you to sleep and doesn't cost too much. Check out the community discussions you can always find coupons for their games for a deep discount if your not sure the cost is right. Check out all their games you will be sure to find something interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027104941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 791, 'last_played': 1420235313}
review:
The art style is FANTASTIC. That is the only positive game element to be had here. Save your money and stay away, regardless of the pandering reviews from what I can only assume are people who have never played tower defense games before. I mean hell, if it wasn't for the art style this thing wouldn't even survive on Miniclip. 

The game feels like a continuing list of bad design choices, a case study in what not to do in a tower defense time. When I complain I feel like a lecturer in basic game design: "encourage strategic play", "present consistent rules for your game world", or maybe "release without game crippling bugs and advancement locks". It's bad enough now, but be greatful you weren't playing when the campaign tech tree was locked and you'd be forced to menu-delete a game when an armored enemy type showed up an you had no units capable of damaging it. 

Almost every mistake (as I'm coming to call them, because I honestly don't think any of them were actually thought through properly), is at once trivially annoying and long term game breaking. Manually resetting and time consumingly repicking your tech tree to deal with new enemy types every level may seem simply irritating, but gradually emerges into an overall expectation that you pick the "right" tech tree that enables victory, and all others will fail by default. Having to painfully micromanage your reloads is grating, and eventually ensures that every strategy will be limited to your clicktimes and not your strategy, dooming any kind of open-world defense. And the rediculous armor and repulsion systems vex you piece by piece as your weapons and equipment become obsolete, before finally running the final, game destroying flaw: you will not lose when your defenses are overwhelmed, you will lose when the charming little boxlike enemies have countered every possible defense and your entire list of defensive options have become obsolete. 

It's like the equiptment they give you is just a taunt of what your strategy could have been: oh hey, here's a rapid fire turret. Too bad it does no damage to enemies after level 4, when they all have armor. Hey, check out these repulsion buildings to herd the enemy into chokepoints. Sucks that every other enemy after level 6 has become "intelligent" and will simply run up and eat them. Laser weapons? Armor reflects them - useless. Slowing razor field units? Can't be used with the anti-armor explosive guns, which destroy all your own buildings, including your own defenses, because apparently future scientists drink too much coffee to understand friend-foe ID. Similarly, saving up money in the campaign feels rewarding until you find out that the game raises the difficulty with your cash level and thus it's advantagous to avoid any kind of strategic spending. RotT plays like a cod game, where every interesting idea gets thrown out within ten minutes because it happens to be too fun and interesting to keep using. 

I like playing tower defense games because of the evolution of your goals and the resource management involved. I'm not sure I like playing them when resource management is a menial clusterf*** and the evolution of methods is only happening in the enemy forces. I've never had a tower defense game where I've felt so much like *I* was the computer, and the enemy forces were actually the human, getting to play adaptively against me with all the strategy and choice-making I was missing. Playing like a bot isn't a good feeling. I do not recommend playing like a bot. I do not recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013359559', 'num_games_owned': 538, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 593, 'last_played': 1420235481}
review: This is an open field tower defence game; that is to say that it is a cross between a tower defence and a base building RTS. Combined with a tech matrix, this adds another (second) dimension to standard tower defense games. It is not easy to beat but is easy to play. Its tropish and cute style is amusing and the story progression introduces new and varied monsters almost every level. A decent length of play and replayability as you use different technologies with your strategies to beat maps.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022636031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 561, 'last_played': 1559777301}
review: This is an awesome tower defense game. The interesting mix of power-up, upgrades and new weapons have to be selected carefully for the successful completion of challenging levels.  The laser and droids are particularly damaging.  The balance between opposing forces is very tight.  The chances of being over-run by those nasty Titans is great, especially during a ghost swarm.  Recent versions have improved greatly the access to the technology tree with a single upgrade now available at the end of all campaign levels.  I'm not too into retro graphics but I really like the level introductions, animations and sound effects. 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197996516587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 86400}
review: I tried to like this but after giving it several attempts I can't say I do. The RTS/tower defense hybrid just doesn't work for me. It's very difficult but that difficulty feels cheap and unfair. Too many random conditions and the AI doesn't follow easily definable rules. If there were some rogue-like elements that let you build upon your failures that would do a lot for this game, but as it is I can't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996632683', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1451621710}
review:
an immensely approachable, mad little tower defence game (dev is from the west country). GSOH, fun animations, music that isn't awful, just generally a very friendly diversion with lots of scope for idle fiddling of your build and optimising your strategies. I'm often trawling walkthroughs and guides even in single player games, but this is well-crafted enough that I was led by the nose through some smart strategies and had little to gain from a deeper understanding of the mechanics -- it's all very lucid and intelligible, despite the themed humour.

Just be prepared to lose buildings. Pretend they're unmanned or something.

Also, support is great, despite it literally being the dev afaik.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992382723', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 664, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 663, 'last_played': 1513394819}
review:
This quite a good tower defense game. It's not a strict-pathing one, where there's a grid and you can easily decide what routes the enemies will take. This one is free-form. The aliens come from designates spots, but can take various paths to get to their objectivs.

The upgrade system is quite large and interesting, as there are definite paths through the upgrade tree.

The graphics and sound have a really cool retro vibe to them. There are several modes to play, and many hours of fun to be had.

The levels (that I've encountered so far) don't have a super-nitpicky quality to them. I'm referring to those moments in other TDs where you say to yourself, "If that one alien had died, I'd have had that extra $10 to buy that tower that would have kept me alive." You really get the feeling that it's your overall strategy that determines whether you win or lose.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044797961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 216, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 634, 'last_played': 1415402603}
review: A retro Tower Defense casual game, maybe fine for portables, but it must be redesigned for Pc. The graphics are so minimalists that some differences, upgrades and texts are hard to see even in full screen. Effects are so annoying that is better deactivate them. Gives few time to building before a level start, spaces between buildings are uncertain, and no offers a full overview of scenaries. Foes can leave paths, march to anywhere and crush structures easily because weapons do little without power-ups, only a handfull are really usefull. Mining is low yield... A nightmare for defensive planning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120282764', 'num_games_owned': 811, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 924, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1415031638}
review: It's more like a rts with no mobile units in your arsenal rather than a tower defense with actual planning phase. Game gives you little to no time to prepare and expects you to be constantly on the lookout up to eigh sides of the map after randomly creating your base on an open spot. The problem is, map control is bad so you have to scroll to all sides placing stuff and repeat it hundred times so it gets boring quickly. And although repick option before every level on your tech tree is nice, it gets almost mandatory to repick and redesign everything half game. Won't really recommend for that price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020611739', 'num_games_owned': 585, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1414363207}
review: Genial, un tower defense bastante activo, con una estetica que me ha parecido muy acertada y con importancia de que desarrollamos y cuando en los laboratorios.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973274983', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1232, 'last_played': 1466612686}
review:
At first, the game looks like your regular TD, with towers and upgrades and such, but as you progress through the game, you realize that there is alot of shit you need to research that you didn't, which can create some pretty hectic battles. There are a few rules that are always constant, but there are major gamechangers as you move from planet to planet. If a map is too hard on campaign mode, you can generate a different map in less than a second. The game promises an intense, blitzkrieg set of battles that will keep you sweating, and many different ways of dispatching the hordes of titans. Like manually zapping you enemies? buy capacitors. Want your buildings to do the work? Buy defenses. Feel like taking the fight to them? Droid and tank factories. In short:
Unique gameplay
Brutaly fast and decisive combat
Varying degrees of difficulty.
666/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198134194078', 'num_games_owned': 992, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 98, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1473226276}
review:
Cute. Funny. Deep. Revenge of the Titans is a game I find highly enjoyable! I happen to like Tower Defense games and RTS games and RotT does it right. You have to research things to be allowed to use them, so be careful what you click on the research page! They don't just GIVE you what you need, but they do hint at it for you. Gameplay wise it's a simple concept of "Defend your base", but the execution can be complex! At first they are just marching at you, but new enemy types and larger numbers as you progress makes you have to think quick! Delete an old turret and place a new one, shut down an old refinery that has done it's job for a quick financial injection you may need to put up more barricades! When you're attacked anywheres the games screen jumps a bit and the titans make noises to distract you too! It all adds up to a hectic yet lovely time. As long as your careful you might pull through!

Music, Art and Gameplay in one package! Buy it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972433110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1412895989}
review: The tech tree, different titans, and procedurally generated maps make this game an enjoyable challenge.  The 'respec' feature enables you to try different weapons and tactics.  I've found some levels that I could not beat without rethinking my strategy and tech selections.  Overall, itâ€™s a fun game for any fan of tower defense.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027141250', 'num_games_owned': 1727, 'num_reviews': 178, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1413064302}
review:
This game looked like it would be fun, but the decision to make this a click-fest has ruined the fun for me. Some people may enjoy a game where you are frantically jumping around the map, but to me tower defense is about planning defenses, not lighting reflexes.

The single biggest problem is that you can't build while paused and only have a few seconds at the beginning of the mission to build your refineries and set up your defenses before the enemies start coming, ready or not. The enemies don't follow consistent paths and can easily destroy your towers, which means that in the mad rush to get towers down they won't be placed optimally and will probably be destroyed, wasting money that comes all too slowly from refineries.

This snowballs with the fact that your finances carry between missions, so if you spent all your money and barely passed a difficult mission, you'll be broke at the beginning of the next mission. This punishes the player for not playing perfectly and makes some of the later missions basically impossible because you didn't play the early game just right. The difficulty also scales with your finances so you have to be in the sweet spot of enough money to build enough towers but not too much money that your get overwhelmed before you know what is going on.

At least the game isn't as clicky and punishing as it used to be, in earlier versions you had to manually click on refineries to harvest them and turrets to reload them and the tech tree used to be yet another source of punishment to inexperienced players so there might be some hope for this game, but at this point I still don't recommend it unless you like a rather punishing, frantic click-fest.
