author: {'steamid': '76561198039827748', 'num_games_owned': 508, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1798, 'last_played': 1580687400}
review:
Tower defense games seem to come in two sorts these days: those where stages are played like an RTS from an overhead view and those where you get down into the trenches FPS-style. Revenge of the titans is by far my favorite game in the former category. This is because the range of options it provides, and the incentives it offers to explore them, make it much more centered on creative design than anything else in the genre I've yet played.

Titans works essentially like every other tower defense game: set up defenses around something, a wave of baddies swoops in to destroy that something, you must manage your defenses in real time until the stage is complete. But Revenge also has some features which differentiate it. The pixel-art graphics are charming, though they can be a bit confusing in the thick of battle. If you've played anything else by Puppy Games you'll know what I mean as this style is their trademark. Personally, I think it another great strength of the game, though it may not be everyoneâ€™s cup of tea.

The stages are very large and very open. The defenses you construct are not bound by a grid, and will likely consist of many, many components rather than just a handful of parts. The size also adds to the challenge: enemies enter the map from many different points in a single stage and are can be difficult to coral.  

All this gives you a considerable amount of freedom in coming up with a defensive plan. Many towers interact, so you will be designing and placing installations with scores of interrelated parts, not just putting up some towers on established paths. 

Complementing that freedom is a component of management and upgrading. There are two aspects to this: first, there is a deep upgrade tree which, over time, grants you access to new and better towers. This provides a variety of weapons and defenses, but also forces the player to choose which to ultimately prioritize meaning that by game's end you can have very different sets of advanced tools at your disposal. Second, the resources you use to build must be procured during stages via mining, and your balance caries over from level to level. (Thus, in typical PuppyGames fashion, how you play in one stage carries over into subsequent stages.) The fact that your starting resources for the next stage are what remains from the last makes the game into a campaign, and provides an added incentive to devise elegant defense solutions which conserve resources. 

Both of these features can mean that itâ€™s possible to get into a situation where a stage simply isnâ€™t feasible due to your prior decisions and mistakes. Conveniently, you can return to any prior stage at any time and play forward again, so your decisions are only as set-in-stone as you want them to be. I found that this actually created replayability, as I went back to try and conduct a better campaign. On the other hand, there were a few points where I found I needed technologies in ways I couldnâ€™t anticipate and had to backtrack to get them.

To sum up, Revenge of the Titans is a tower defense game that gives you space to invent and a reason to do it. If you like the traditional tower defense genre and also enjoy the sort of creative design typical to good sim games there are hours of fun for you in Revenge of the Titans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063185839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1411600455}
review: Cool game :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198000672969', 'num_games_owned': 436, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1068, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1066, 'last_played': 1416257062}
review:
This is a highly polished, innovative Tower Defense - on a par if not outright superior to Kingdom Rush. Good writing, interesting mechanics and some useful updates that have significantly improved the game. Encourages a variety of approaches. Soundtrack and assests are all top notch.

PuppyGames games continues their signature aesthetic - sleek polychromatic retro, with great post effects. 

I picked it up in a bundle, but it is well worth it's asking price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995346518', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1396329294}
review: For a tower defense game itâ€™s a lot fun, but be warned, it is very difficult.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040884867', 'num_games_owned': 2418, 'num_reviews': 901, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1325750400}
review:
Tower defense game with the nice mechanic of being able to put the towers anywhere. Cool artwork, music, and upgrade system. Like most tower defense games, there is alot of content here. My only freakin' problem is that I hit a hard wall and got stuck; I cannot get past the level I am on. I am not new to tower defense games (I own and have finished all the big ones).

Difficulty just ramped up too quickly and ruined my experience. Unfortunatley I would not recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970541654', 'num_games_owned': 820, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 851, 'last_played': 1520191577}
review:
Fantastic tower defense game. Currently available for Â£6.99, which is an absolute steal for the amount of gameplay you will get from this great game. With a lovely retro feel to the graphics and audio but with clever games design throughout you won't be disappointed. With many ways to play through the campaign by following different tech trees this game will offer you 20+ hours of gameplay.

Check it out :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198073946138', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1229, 'last_played': 1419402000}
review: I wasn't sure if I should get this because I wasn't to much into tower defence games, but after playing it I found it awesome. Some parts it may get very challenging but it pays off. There is comedy to the game, science, adventure  and creativity. I recomend this game to every one. It has a simple concept, place turrets, kill titans, win.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983904576', 'num_games_owned': 927, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1325145600}
review: A great arcade-style game that is very addicting. Even though I usually don't like RTS or tower defense, I liked the simplicity and good design of the game. It is difficult to master without being difficult to learn, with a stylized style reminiscent of an ultra-modern Advance Wars.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038604011', 'num_games_owned': 914, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 570, 'last_played': 1404857210}
review:
I suppose this is most closely a tower defense game, but it has some pretty deep strategy/economy elements to it. The graphics and aesthetic are pleasing for the most part and I suppose there's a good amount of content to keep you engaged throughout the campaign. However, my time with it mostly consisted of boredom. I'm rubbish at games like this, and because of that I don't ever play them on any difficulty beyond easy. This could definitely be to blame for the boredom, but when I start struggling at higher difficulties in tower defense games I tend to quickly just lose interest and stop having fun. 

I personally would not recommend this to anyone, but I'm not a fan of the genre so what would I know :p

author: {'steamid': '76561198012801273', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1616885390}
review:
The art style in this game is very pleasing to the eye and unique. It's so simple yet attractive. Now the game is rather hard wich means proper planning is needed to complete a level, but with so many technology choices you can play the game the way you want.
It's not a standart Tower Defense game since aliens don't really follow the roads. I'd recommend for people who are tired of normal Tower Defense games because this one takes it to the next level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008369673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1407962377}
review:
I do like this game...however I do not like it as much as I thought I would.  Its not to say its a bad game, oh no no no, its actually pretty decent, just I feel it suffers from some oversights.

Basically you have to defend your base from the oncoming hoards of Titans, using what ever you have researched and are available.  Ok simple enough.  You get an icon showing the direction the hoards are coming from and you build accordingly.  Just on some missions, during my play time, I find that an all important hoard direction marker is actually hidden/obscured by my HUD, which lead to my defences getting demolished because I didnt see said marker.

But really...tis a minor gripe, if annoying.  The actual gameplay is pretty simple, just point and click to deploy your stuff or click and drag for multiples, so nice and easy to get your defences where you need them/want them to be.  Research is pretty easy to understand with icons showing what needs what to be available, though the game does tend to recommend tech to you if you havent got it, so it kinda takes it out of your hands a bit, by basically saying " you need this, not what you are currently thinking "  Though you can ignore that.  But it does offer you respec points for your research so you can get what you want within you resorce point limit at the time, so thats a pretty useful feature.

Graphically I like it, its a nice and different style to see.  I particulary like how the Titans are designed, especially the sub-bosses.  

But one other thing that gets me is the price.  I would not pay the Â£7 it was advertised for.  Fun fact, I recieved a 90% off this game coupon from Steam by crafting a badge, so I had it for 70p!  So what I would do, if this game interests you, is get a coupon or wait for it to come on sale at around 33% off at minimum and then I would say its worth it.

Not a bad game, just a few little issues and a bit over-priced, but it is alright.  Should cure your Tower Defence itch for a little while.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992567771', 'num_games_owned': 2159, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1376746410}
review:
Revenge of the Titans ist ein Tower Defense Spiel von einem kleinen englischen Entwicklerstudio.
Auf der Erde ist die HÃ¶lle los, die Titanen greifen unerbittlich an und versuchen die Erde zu vernichten. Das lassen die Menschen natÃ¼rlich nicht auf sich sitzen und versuchen den Titanen Einhalt zu gebieten, mit einem neuen Commander und der bist du.

Das Spiel spielt sich Ã¤hnlich wie ein Tower Defense Spiel. Am Anfang eines Levels versucht man sofort mÃ¶glichst viele Raffinerien bei den grÃ¼nen Kristallen zu errichten damit man mÃ¶glichst schnell an Geld kommt das man wiederum in die Verteidigung des StÃ¼tzpunktes verwerten muss.

 Die GebÃ¤ude zur Rohstoffgewinnung wie die TÃ¼rme lassen sich auf der Karte frei platzieren. Das schafft spielerische Freiheit macht das ganze aber auch schwieriger da dadurch die Titanen natÃ¼rlich auch frei herumlaufen. Im Normalfall lÃ¤uft es so ab das man gewarnt wird aus welcher Ecke die Titanen kommen und kann dann noch schnell genug reagieren um die Verteidigung auf diesen Punkt zu konzentrieren. Im Laufe des Spieles kommen die Titanen immer zahlreicher aus den Ecken der Karte sodass man oft an vielen Orten gleichzeitig beschÃ¤ftigt ist.

Nach jeder Runde darf man einen Punkt in die Forschung investieren. Dabei kann man unter anderem neue WaffentÃ¼rme, VerstÃ¤rkungen, Spezialwaffen oder neue Technologien erforschen. Das ist auch bitter nÃ¶tig denn die Titanen werden auch sehr schnell stÃ¤rker und zahlreicher. Man muss sich aufgrund der groÃŸen Herausforderung schnell fÃ¼r eine Richtung der Forschung entscheiden und diese schnell voran treiben damit man mit den Titanen mithalten kann.

Das ganze geht soweit das man in den einzelnen Runden gehetzt von einer Richtung zur anderen jagt und immer wieder schnell eine paar neue GebÃ¤ude hinstellt. Das fÃ¼hlt sich gut an, wird auf Dauer aber zÃ¤h und anstrengend, da man den Titanen spÃ¤ter immer nur hinterher lÃ¤uft und nie die Oberhand hat. Das ganze hÃ¤tte man mit einem optionalen Schwierigkeitsgradregler besser lÃ¶sen kÃ¶nnen.

Die Grafik sieht mit ihrem Comic Look echt toll aus, der Soundtrack, der auch elektronische Versionen von alten deutschen Klassikern besitzt, geht sofort ins Ohr und setzt sich fest, auch die sonstigen Soundeffekte sind toll und passen zum Spiel. Das brabbeln des Generals oder des Forschers hÃ¶rt sich einfach toll an. Normalerweise bin ja nicht so ein Fan von elektronischer Musik, aber das Titellied von diesem Spiel ist eines der besten elektronischen Lieder die ich kenne, das originale Lied ist auch zu empfehlen, man sollte zumindest einmal rein hÃ¶ren wie Ã¤hnlich sich das anhÃ¶rt.

Revenge of the Titans ist ein tolles kleines Spiel fÃ¼r Zwischendurch und macht einfach SpaÃŸ, man stÃ¼rzt zwar die meiste Zeit gehetzt durchs Spiels aber das macht auch irgendwie den Reiz aus es immer wieder erneut zu versuchen und stÃ¤rker zu werden. Es gibt im Spiel einige Bossgegner die besonders hartnÃ¤ckig sind, einen aber mit viel Geld belohnen. Nach dem besiegen eines Bossgegners kommt man immer auf einen Planeten und so geht es von der Erde zum Mond bis zum Mars und noch viel weiter, bis zur Heimat der Titanen.

FÃ¼r Spieler die auf schnelle harte Tower Defense Spiele fÃ¼r Zwischendurch stehen ist Revenge of the Titans wirklich zu empfehlen.

is not that exciting as I imagine, I love the 3d art that they use for the cover for this game,

author: {'steamid': '76561198019334464', 'num_games_owned': 1241, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 520, 'last_played': 1404754219}
review:

[b]Full review[/b] is available [url=http://www.highlandarrow.com/reviews/118-review-revenge-of-the-titans.html]here[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561197994195516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1451232521}
review:
Nice tower defense game. I am usually not a big fan of these, but this is a nice one. It has some twists on the normal tower defense in for example it does not have traditional maze building. You place your towers along the route of the emenies and not blocking them, else they will be destoyed quickly. Luckily the towers build instantly so you can place them as soon as you guestimate the route the enemies will take. The decent size research tree and enemy varienty keeps the levels fresh while your are going through the campaign. The difficulty level is not too frustratingly hard, while still giving you a proper challenge.

It is not perfect though, the game explains the mechanics badly and you have to figure out (too) much yourself and the inability too zoom out of the map and not having a mini-map can make navigating and keeping an eye on the field a pain sometimes in having to pan the screen like mad.

On a discount this game is definitely worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993248610', 'num_games_owned': 664, 'num_reviews': 176, 'playtime_forever': 1140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 886, 'last_played': 1677721667}
review: Never found a tower defence game i wanted to get into, but the art sytle on titan drew me in. I had a lot of fun playing threw this game and left wanting more... which is always a good thing. Sandbox mode allows you to play community made maps and create your own. I wanted this to be an extension to the game, it might still be, but I haven't found that there yet. I can't wait for a secound Revenge of the Titans, grab it if you can.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104562303', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 917, 'last_played': 1404795752}

review: A fun little game that has a interesting research "tree" and constantly growing enemies.Your choices in what you research can mean the death of you or a easy win depending on what you use.However I would only recommend buying this game if it is on some kind of sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130289856', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1410268054}
review: I'd say the description do not tell enough about the game. To say its a tower defense only game. You are lucky to have the video and print screens. Needs some more descriptions set into the game such as a proper tutorial i dont think the one at the moment is suitable for all players such as people who is newbie to tower defense games. Currently this game is granted 2/5 stars from my side. Improve and i hope you all do it the way the players (you) want it to be...but with proper introduction to it....and not to much conversations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072565295', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 580, 'last_played': 1403988281}
review:
"It was ok, 4/10" -IGN

But please, get this game, it's excellent. It's like a tower defense but more dynamic.

My friend gifted this to me when my arm broke. I was excited to try it out because I only had one hand so TF2 was impossible to play. The time I spent playing this while recovring was well worth it.

Get it while it's $1.00, you'll love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022571209', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1407922002}
review:
Ho trovato questo gioco molto carino e ben fatto. Lo sconsiglio a chi non vuole impegnarsi perchÃ¨ ogni livello della campagna sarÃ  affrontato a difficoltÃ  massima che si abbasserÃ  solo se si viene sconfitti.

Il gameplay Ã¨ semplice: difendere la base dall'orda di Titans piazzando torrette, muri e altri edifici. L'unica risorsa in gioco sono i soldi ottenibili al completamento di ogni missione o durante il gioco con degli edifici speciali. All'inizio di ogni missione  ci saranno due personaggi: un vecchio generale baffuto con un occhio cibernetico che ci spiegherÃ  che cosa dobbiamo aspettarci e uno scienziato occhialuto che ci illustra i nuovi alieni in arrivo. La varietÃ  di titans Ã¨ un pregio anche se differiscono solo dalla velocitÃ , HP e armatura. (fortunatamente non hanno abilitÃ  speciali).
Graficamente Ã¨ povero perÃ² gli sviluppatori sono stati in grado di mettere dei bei filtri vecchio stile: lo schermo risulta "piegato agli angoli" stile televisore a tubo catodico con le righe generate dai raggi catodici. Durante il briefing puÃ² capitare che lo schermo sfarfalli e questo accade anche in missione quando i titans attaccano  (caratteristica molto fastidiosa che perÃ² si puÃ² tranquillamente disattivare in ogni momento).
Il gioco non Ã¨ molto longevo e a coloro che piacciono gli RTS risulterÃ  quasi semplice (Quasi!) per il resto lo consiglio perÃ² solo scontato perchÃ¨ 10â‚¬ sono un po' tantini per quello che offre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033802030', 'num_games_owned': 2082, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 1038, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 938, 'last_played': 1389201293}
review:
Game: Revenge of the Titans
Summary: A fun, somewhat unattractive tower defense game 
Rating (5/10 = failure): 8/10
Multiplayer: No
Completion: 17 hrs
Cards: Yes
Cloud: Yes
Cost:  ~1 USD bundled

Oh wow, a story! It's mostly for kicks, but at least it gave me a reason to play (as sarcastic as that sounds, I actually mean it. I feel like there was a point to all that).

The research system is fantastic. It may look daunting to the first-timer, but once I got used to it, I started to wish it was even bigger. As it is, it's good.

While I'm sure it's meant as part of its aesthetics, the battle environments always look... sterile and off-putting. I would have liked to see some daytime areas, forests, cities. Maybe more weather effects like rain and snow outside of X-mas. Instead we get... rocks. And more rocks. In pale pastel colors. Add to that an ever-present, pointless dim spotlight effect which makes everything look dull and dim. On every stage. It's a fun game, but borderline unappealing and somewhat hard on the eyes.

I'm not sure if I was playing it correctly, but I had difficulty setting up towers along paths, as creeps would invariably destroy those towers (not including the creeps that specifically go for towers). In any case, it didn't matter in the end, as I found that on most maps I could just make a super defense perimeter around the base and nothing would get past it except for boss monsters, in which case, all that required was a second set of towers attacking the boss right away.

The automatic difficulty scaling could use some work. Once you get the hang of the game, you'll quickly start to rake in funds. But if you do too well (+50k in funds), the game gives you zilch next stage. It feels like it's punishing you for doing well, and even without looking it up, I could tell the game was "cheating" by doing that.

Out of all the Puppygames, I regard this one as the best. It's not frustrating, it's not brutally hard, has a good length, several game modes, and even the stages I failed it didn't remain failed for long.

review:

Quand on dÃ©bloque pas mal de recherche Ã§a deviens interessant sans casser trois pattes Ã  un canard. Principal point fort: c'est addictif et ca a un fort gÃ´ut de reviens-y. point faible: graphiquement trop pixellisÃ© et grossier a mont gout (un peu marre de cette tendance pixel qui t'amene a te demander si tu dois changer de lunettes ou si ton Ã©cran est mal rÃ©glÃ©!).
Les ennemis ressemblent au fantÃ´mes dans pac-man ouais bon... y a mieux. Les tourelles sont moches aussi mais l'ensemble vaut quand mÃªme le coup.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009511609', 'num_games_owned': 881, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 661, 'last_played': 1445811134}
review:
Does an interesting take on the Tower Defense genre.  No single columns here, but actual area control and tactical choke points allowing you to determine how much land you want to defend.

Pros:  
- Difficulty Curve is challenging, but fair.  Enemy strength adapts to the amount of $$ you have, so you always have a shot at winning a level.
- Tech tree has FREE RESPECS.
- The music is awesome.
- Start play from any level you've already beaten, see what would have changed if you hadn't barely won that level, but steamrolled it instead!

Cons:  
- Its sometimes easy to back yourself into a corner with very little money, and no way to defend a sprawling map to allow you to build up your funds again.

Tips:
- Save your powerups for boss levels (every 10th).  They're incredibly helpful there.
- Mines are your friend and can take care of a whole advancing column for a minute or more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048871343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1451606577}
review: This game offers a different take on the tower defense genre.  I normally dislike tower defense games, but this game is one of my all time favorites. The great variation in levels keeps the game from getting repetitive. The visuals are crisp and shiny yet retro inspired, and the sound track is amazing.  The auto scaling difficulty ensures that all players will find a challenge regardless of skill level. As you should, always research before you purchase, but I assure you this game is a real gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087858262', 'num_games_owned': 428, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1443319251}
review: Revenge of the Titans is the perfect mix between a tower defense game and a RTS game. The game is difficult, but just to the point where it keeps me coming back. There is a wide range of towers to choose from and many different strategies that can be used. I suggest this game if you enjoy tower defense games, and need a game to play when you're bored.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010180088', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 930, 'last_played': 1392874116}
review:
[b]This review is rather long, so if you just want a small summary of why I recommend this game skip to [u]Results[/u] and read from there.[/b]

Puppygames develops an awesome tower defense game which changes the elements of your traditional TD. The awesome research options between levels, harvesting of resources, and the variety of tools to change alien tactics creates a unique experience between each level. 

[b]Campaign:[/b]
Revenge of the Titans, obviously you know the name as you are looking at this review. This game offers an interesting differentiation onto a typical Tower Defense game; enemies destroy your towers and the idea is to block the path rather than create a route. The world is being attacked by an alien species from Jupiterâ€™s moon Titan. The name of the game seems to make me believe maybe we attacked them first? But yet again there is no real story other than the world is under attack and you are chosen to lead the defense force. You not only defend the earth, but you progress through the solar system defeating the alien scum at each planet until you finally arrive to Titan. Each planet has about ten levels, each which offer new bosses and pose new challenges that keep you on your toes. 

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
The towers are upgraded by placing upgrading towers adjacent to towers. This is interesting as you can place multiple add-on towers adjacent to a tower to create rapid fire towers, or even long range sniper towers. The difficulty curve seems rather perplexing, with little explanation onto how to play this game can seem rather difficult till you figure it out. The game is incredibly entertaining, once you figure out the general gameplay you can really get into this game. You are given one upgrade point per level which you can use to customize your defense force. With about 73 upgrades and only 50 levels means you cannot research every possible option. The game allows you to respec after each mission, which allows you to manipulate your towers to achieve optimal defenses for each level. When playing the campaign make sure you remember that your money transfers between levels (and your towers automatically sell returning funds from the towers). This information is useful, as you can start saving early making the later levels easier. If you mess up after beating a level and lose too much money you can go back replay the level prior to it and fix your mistakes. This allows you to bring a better end result and alter your starting cash in the next mission. 

[b]Results:[/b]
Revenge of the Titans is an epic tower defense game that drives in new challenges and creates new concepts not seen in previous games of the same genre. The campaign is long and difficult, on the standard setting, but you can make it easier at the drop of a hat. Each level requires you to respect in order to take advantage of alien weaknesses, but this makes each level dynamic and unique. 

Pros:
+Fast paced tower defense game
+Upgrade screen allows for between match tactic customization
+Transfer of funds between levels means how you play the level before impacts the later levels 
+Power-Ups transfer between levels, so you can easily stack them. (I for example used none of my abilities until the last level to make the final boss incredibly easy).
+Great difficulty curve, if you are a beginner you can significantly reduce the difficulty to ease up the levels. 
+Gameplay from prior levels transfers to the next level, meaning you must play tactfully throughout the entire game. 

Cons:
-Poor tutorials, by the time you figure out all the nuances of the game itâ€™s already over. (I for example didn't realize that levels don't start until you place your first mineral extractor until level 48 - this would have been useful to know early on)
-Recommended upgrades seem rather worthless (itâ€™s better to just rush barricades)
-Not a traditional tower defense (there is no maze building, and to upgrade towers requires add-on towers which can be hard to space)

review: One of the most addicting tower defense games I have played in a LONG time. With tons of upgrades and countless different types of enemies to encounter while trying to protect your command post from being destroyed. The artstyle and music in this game is very cartoony and looks very well done. After you pick a new upgrade, you get a funny little cutscene from either the scientist, or my favorite the general. I can see myself spending A LOT of time on this game in the near future. 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197994037570', 'num_games_owned': 408, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 1272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 907, 'last_played': 1391525915}
review:
Revenge of the Titans is a 2D tower defense game with RTS elements developed by London-based studio Puppy Games. As in all tower defense games, your goal is to halt the oncoming horde of enemies by strategically placing defensive towers that destroy them. In this case, humanity is being attacked by aliens coming from Saturnâ€™s largest moon Titan.

The campaign spans 50 missions across 5 locations (Earth, The Moon, Mars, Saturn and Titan). After youâ€™re done with the 10-hour campaign, you can spend more time with the game in the Endless, Survival and Sandbox modes. Thereâ€™s a good amount of content here. If youâ€™ve played a classic tower defense game, Revenge of the Titans will feel pretty familiar. However, what separates this game from the usual suspects are the subtle yet profound base building and resource gathering elements found in traditional RTS games.

Every map starts with just your base which you have to protect from the Titans. Then you have to build factories that mine crystals in order to make money to be able to purchase other buildings and towers. You also have additional buildings at your disposal such as shield generators, cloaking devices, reloaders, etc. All of these can be unlocked over time in the research screen before every mission. After completing each mission you are awarded with a single research point. Apart from buildings and towers, you can research technological advancements which bring their own benefits to the table. The great thing about the research system is that you can re-spec the entire system before each mission. This enables you to try out different tactics and you will need certain towers and abilities when facing a particular enemy.

Enemies come in a pretty large variety of shapes and sizes and certain missions also throw huge bosses at you which can be very challenging. Certain towers are good for certain enemies, thatâ€™s where the research screen comes into play. You need to pay attention as to what types of enemies are coming so that you can choose the appropriate towers and technologies otherwise youâ€™ll have a pretty hard time finishing a mission.

The game will also randomly distribute power ups and cash bonuses during missions which you will need to manually pick up on the map within a limited time frame. Thereâ€™s also a tower that needs to be used against a certain enemy that you have to manually control. Coupled with the base/add-on/tower building, the situation can get pretty hectic at times and certain elements such as the power up pick ups simply come off as an artificial way to increase the action. It impeded on the strategic element and just feels needlessly overbearing.

That said, Revenge of the Titans nails the addictive and tactical core that makes tower defense games so satisfying. And with the RTS twist, it manages to differentiate itself which is really important as the genre is becoming increasingly crowded. Itâ€™s a good title for newcomers and veterans alike.

7 OUT OF 10 (GOOD)

author: {'steamid': '76561197989987952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 118, 'last_played': 1390798972}
review:
I want to like this game, but I found it swiftly crossing the line from challenging to frustrating. It suffers from the standard RTS problem of too much going on at once. Levels are either too simple and over too soon, or alien swarmfests where there isn't enough room to put a tower in or enough time to figure out what's getting blown up where. Maybe other people enjoy repeating levels a dozen times before things are just right, but I certainly don't.

It provides an easy mode, but that doesn't seem to help with the fundamental issues with the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990112111', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1314, 'last_played': 1390070169}
review:
It's an interesting tower defense game, in the sense it has a campaign, and depending on how you progress through it, a level may be rather easy (with enough funds and boosts saved up), or actually impossible.  The creeps also attack your structures (melee and ranged attacks), which is different from most games in the genre.  It's actually more like a defensive RTS game, in the sense the creeps only loosely follow a path, which is more realistic and varied, but it also means there's little opportunity to exploit their path tactically.  I guess I like everything about the game, but find the actual defense part to be a little unsatisfying.      

For a big TD fan, I would recommend this game, but for the average gamer, looking to play a TD game, I would recommend Defense Grid, Plants vs Zombies, or Sol Survivor (probably in that order) before this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032531136', 'num_games_owned': 581, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 2357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1526, 'last_played': 1667815525}
review:

Revenge of the titans est un tower defense futuriste oÃ¹ le joueur doit dÃ©fendre sa base contre des hordes dâ€™aliens menÃ©s, sur certaines maps, par des boss immenses. Jâ€™ai beaucoup de mÃ©fiance vis-Ã -vis de ce genre de jeu. Jâ€™y ai fait mes dÃ©buts avec les fameux Â«Â levels bonusÂ Â» de Warcraft 3, qui mâ€™avaient Ã©normÃ©ment plut, puis le genre se dÃ©mocratisant, jâ€™ai Ã©tÃ© franchement dÃ©Ã§u par ce qui en ressortait. Souvent mal Ã©quilibrÃ© entre les diffÃ©rentes forces ennemies, leurs vitesses, ou les coÃ»ts dâ€™amÃ©liorations  des Â«Â toursÂ Â» par rapport aux gains effectifs, il Ã©tait temps de remettre les pendules Ã  lâ€™heure, et la tentative des dÃ©veloppeurs de Revenge of the titans sâ€™avÃ¨re plutÃ´t rÃ©ussie. En fait, câ€™est assez malin et vicieux. Plusieurs raisonsÂ : sur la carte de jeu dâ€™abord, il nâ€™y pas de chemins par lesquelles les ennemis iront Ã  la queue leu leu, mais juste des directions gÃ©nÃ©rales dâ€™arrivÃ©es, autrement dit, le positionnement des tours de dÃ©fenses se fait par estimation et en temps rÃ©el. Si vous collectez bien Ã©videmment de lâ€™argent en tuant des ennemis, vous ne le dÃ©pensez que sur la carte de jeu en achetant des tours supplÃ©mentaires. Pour amÃ©liorer (upgrader) vos dÃ©fenses, Ã  chaque map gagnÃ©, on vous octroie une et une seule amÃ©lioration. Mais elle est gratuiteÂ ! Sauf que vous allez en avoir des possibilitÃ©s dâ€™amÃ©liorations, surtout quâ€™elles suivent une arborescence (le cÃ´tÃ© malin)Â ! Du coup, vous tentez une combinaison qui, souvent, a lâ€™air de bien fonctionner pendant un certain laps de temps, jusquâ€™au moment oÃ¹ vous sentez que vous auriez dÃ» la choisir un peu plus tÃ´t ou un peu plus tard (le cÃ´tÃ© vicieux). Et donc, vous recommencez pour valider votre thÃ©orie, sauf que vous vous apercevez quâ€™une autre amÃ©lioration pourrait bien vous aider aussi, etc. Pour les joueurs persÃ©vÃ©rants, Revenge of the titans est un excellent jeu disposant dâ€™une belle durÃ©e de vie. On regrettera une bande-son oubliable et pas spÃ©cialement transcendante comme la majoritÃ© de ses comparses pour ce genre de jeu (pourquoi ne pas faire une musique de plus en plus angoissante ou rythmÃ©e Ã  mesure que les adversaires sâ€™approchent de votre baseÂ ?). Ce jeu aura eu le don de mâ€™intÃ©resser Ã  tous les autres que Puppygames (la boÃ®te de dÃ©veloppement) revisite.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081382083', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 661, 'last_played': 1384106986}
review: If you've every played a Puppy Games game, you know exactly what you are getting here. It takes the basic tower defense formula and turns it completely on its head. It seems to have a hard time scaling the difficulty, late game is very hard, but its good enough that when you fail you keep wanting to come back for more. It has alot of action, but on a slow pace. There are many different enemy types that are all designed well, but all any of them do is pretty much walk at you. The art style is interesting and fairly unique, not something you see alot in games. There is a fairly high level of strategy involved with the amount of different equipment you get over the course of this game, so the game keeps you really thinking. It isn't too punishing in the upgrades department, if something doesn't work you can cash in your upgrades and try out something completly different.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056251012', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 694, 'last_played': 1389877595}
review:
Firstly the game looks funny and there are many interesting ideas implemented but after a while you totaly see what is really unique in this game, the difficulty. Don't get me wrong hard is okay but here it reaches a level thats only interesting for masochistic players.  And here is the reason why I think so, the money and powerups are shared in all missions. And if you had trouble in an earlier mission you start the next world with a useless low amount of money. And powerups, they are much more rare then feral white elephants in Scandinavia. So if you haven't saved enough from both earlier you have to replay the whole campaigne to collect the powerups and money for the final.

No this is not fun, this is not innovativ this is just unneeded timesink!
And whatever the "Restart level on lower difficulty" button does, it is no easier map restart.
Yes, exactly this killed the game for me completly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048062263', 'num_games_owned': 1130, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1381428336}
review: Tower Defense games never gets old. They really do have a lot of appeals to the gamers. This one is no exception. They did it with 8-bit retro graphics, which sometimes can get too 'blurry'. Some higher resolutions would've been nice. The colour scheme is also a bit lacking. The result, a good TD game but visually boring. Don't get me wrong, it IS a good game but there's no 'pull' in it. I didnt feel the need to plow through or to finish next map and the next and the next and the next. You can see that this lasting appeal problem is true from the 'most helpful' positive reviews section had a lot of people who says 'recommended' but had a grand total of single digit hour of playing the game. It's just a bit lacking. There are other better TD games out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058504392', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1193, 'last_played': 1381664500}
review:
Revenge of the Titans is a Strategical(RTS) Tower Defense game where you can either upgrade or expand your arsenal after each round. It can be quite brutal in difficulty at times, but it also forgiving with retrying. I found it a challenging experience with plenty of possible approaches and playstyles to the game.

During play it also actively engages you with player controlled turrets ('ghosts' for example need a special player controlled turret to be killed at first) and it regulary drops some boosters like bombs, freezes, and more or even money to pick up by point and clicking on the battle field. These acquired boosters can be saved cross mission and be used by the player in dire situations. 

The campaign will keep you busy for a while and you can play it differently on another play through. The DLC also offers a sandbox mode. 
In my honest opinion; it's a game you can play, enjoy, put down and re-play again when your bored. The only thing that I would like to see is a multiplayer mode DLC, it very much feels like an expanded version of tower defense games from starcraft and warcraft if you are familiar with it.

Lastly; I found the graphics quite pleasing, it looks simple but everything is clear and its fairly entertaining to look at. The game has its very own identity, and refreshing art style which is further proven by the other games in the same graphical style and theme by Puppy Games.

For the 10 euro's, it is a good buy in any case. As of writing it is on sale for 2 euro's which is dirt cheap, I'd recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006357720', 'num_games_owned': 1700, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1615269413}
review:
[b]TL;DR: A great Tower Defense game, worth the full price, great deal as a bundle around holiday time.[/b]

First, one of the only points of contention I have with this game is the price-point (which can be said about the bulk of Puppygame games).  That being said, this title is actually worth the $10 they're asking.  

Cross-platform tower defense is always nice to have in the library.  Low system requirements means that the game could potentially be played on an older netbook (depending on model, of course).  Fun, with a decent replay value, this game stacks up with some of the heftier titles in the genre with a unique graphical style and play that makes it perfect to add to any library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116682978', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1014, 'last_played': 1437510120}
review:
A worthy sequel to 2013's hit anime Attack on Titan.
This is a charming, atmospheric, tense and stressful tower defense/RTS hybrid with a lot of customization and arcade-like campaigns. It's a bit fiddly and you can fail [i]spectacularly[/i], but still - it's a very entertaining and rewarding game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005648447', 'num_games_owned': 5285, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1387790737}
review:
RotT n'est pas vraiment un tower-defense comme les autres puisqu'ici aucune grille de placement n'existe et il est possible de placer ses tours un peu n'importe oÃ¹ - et au dÃ©but, n'importe comment, ce que l'on finit par payer trÃ¨s vite. Les ennemis arrivent donc continuellement par plusieurs entrÃ©es et il n'est pas rÃ©ellement possible de les canaliser : les crÃ©atures n'attendant que de dÃ©vorer tout ce qui s'y trouve et les tours prennent l'aggro suivant leur efficacitÃ©. Chaque partie peut donc changer du tout au tout, et il arrive que l'on s'y remette Ã  plusieurs fois parce qu'un bout de terrain non protÃ©gÃ© permet aux ennemis de se faufiler ou qu'inversement une partie de notre dÃ©fense se verra martyrisÃ©e au second restart. En l'absence de pause - sauf au dÃ©but oÃ¹ les ennemis n'arrivent que lors de la premiÃ¨re raffinerie posÃ©e - le gameplay se veut donc trÃ¨s arcade et terriblement stressant : il est vite vu d'Ã©tablir quelques tours que l'on devra revendre car leur placement est mal optimisÃ©.

Voyez le jeu davantage comme un STR classique : on y collecte des ressources en raffinant des gisements de minerai Ã  chaque mission, ressources qui seront alors utilisÃ©es pour la construction des tours et conservÃ©es entre chaque mission. Entre chaque mission vous pourrez alors dÃ©penser un point de recherche dans un arbre technologique vaste. Vous posez peu de tours afin de gagner quelques sous pour plus tard au risque d'en voir certaines dÃ©truites sous les assauts rÃ©pÃ©tÃ©s des Titans ou alors allez-vous utiliser un maximum de ressources en prenant le risque de rencontrer des difficultÃ©s lors de la prochaine mission - bien qu'il soit possible de refaire les missions prÃ©cÃ©dentes afin d'optimiser son Ã©conomie ? Le jeu est alors excessivement difficile et Ã  sa sortie beaucoup de joueurs ont abandonnÃ© une fois arrivÃ©s sur Mars ou Saturne. D'autant plus qu'il Ã©tait possible de s'y perdre dans l'arbre de technologie et de devoir tout recommencer afin de rÃ©tablir une nouvelle stratÃ©gie. DÃ©sormais, aprÃ¨s la demande des joueurs, il existe un mode facile comme alternative pour espÃ©rer voir le bout de la campagne, mais aussi une option de respec de l'arbre de technologies et la possibilitÃ© dans les options de dÃ©sactiver le rÃ©glage automatique de la difficultÃ© ; celui-ci augmentant le degrÃ© de challenge si vous aviez une bourse bien pleine.

C'est donc une expÃ©rience hardcore dÃ©sormais possiblement abordable par le commun des mortels, et rafraichissante pour le genre, surtout que le jeu est accompagnÃ© d'une esthÃ©tique envoutante - la musique du menu place tout de suite l'ambiance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024950356', 'num_games_owned': 226, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1387727515}
review:
A questionable game. The core gameplay is your usual tower defense: place shooty towers to shoot the monsters, place buffy towers to buff the shooty towers, place special towers to do other things like acquire more money. This part is fairly solid.

I can't stand the wrapper, though. To start with, upgrades have misleading mouseover descriptions. The game is played on a small map where monsters appear from the fuzzy dark edge and quickly approach your base. With this in mind, you might think that researching the Scanner (description: "Long range detection systems using radar and lidar imaging to improve early alien detection") would extend the map a bit, giving you more space in which to place towers and shoot monsters.
But no, the Scanner is actually a buffy tower that increases the firing range of the tower it's placed next to! No "detection" is involved.

In addition to this misinformation, the campaign mode is very unfriendly to going back and trying to improve your score. Suppose that you've advanced to (for example) level 6 of the campaign, and you're not happy with your performance, so you decide to go back and replay level 3 to accumulate more points there.
The extra points from a better completion of level 3 are not granted to your global resource pool on the campaign map, but to your next play of level 4. Thus, you'll have to replay level 4 and level 5 as well in order to get the new advantages transferred to level 6. In general, you won't be playing with your best results - you'll be playing with your most recent results, which makes it frustrating to attempt to improve your record.

The "Distortion FX" setting that is on by default and jostles your screen at irregular intervals, and the typos in technology descriptions, are just icing on the cake. Perhaps these things are meant to appeal to some sort of misguided realism, but when I'm blowing up alien titans with nanotechnology weapons, I don't want the absurd realism of having low-quality flickering displays because the war caused a power shortage and my character couldn't get spare parts delivered. I want an interface that lets me focus on the gameplay, and the lack of such an interface is the worst fault that I found with Revenge of the Titans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035285721', 'num_games_owned': 5109, 'num_reviews': 1098, 'playtime_forever': 1371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1410686857}
review:
Damn. What you have done to them? Doesn't matter. Now they're here on planet earth and want their revenge. 
This little tower defense game does not even feel like a real TD game. That's very positive. You always struggle for life when hordes of Titans seamly relentless jump/run/fly to your base to destroy it. Built turrets/lasercannons use mines/powerups and shields ... it's insane, the possibilities are countless and every round you research a new technology which is perfectly explained by a crazy scient named Dr. Zed. The aim is to push them back in the solar system, finally to the moon Titan where they obviously came from. 
The graphics are rogue-like, arcade style, black with neon elements, like the other Puppygames. BTW I think, this is the best of them all. I recommend to disable monitor flicker in options menu which is only cosmetical but not very helpful.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986660209', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1358668800}
review:
This game is unbalenced, as in you can actually take and look at the cold hard numbers and notice without trying that it is unbalenced. I'm not even kidding there are literally things in the game that can be proven to be only there to waste money slow down the rate you get money AND waste research points.
The developer of the game flat out admits that they balence the game based on their "feel" rather than actually checking if those numbers made sense or if parts of the game only existed to waste your time.
Don't even get me started on research, the research system is full of vaguely worded topics of nebulous values, things like refineries, reprocessors and collectors are coded specifically to be not worth it in most situations, whereas other things are required to move forward through the game but aren't useful until they are essential.

In short this is a game about trial and error, and if you do decide to buy it do an in depth read of the wiki to find out how much of the research tree, towers(in a tower defense game), and other things that have been specifically hammered down to be as marginally useful as possible to the point where using some of them is a surefire way to lose.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997194879', 'num_games_owned': 354, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1496663404}
review:
By combining Real-time Strategy and Tower Defense, Revenge of the Titans offers more than a good tower defense game. It looks great, performs well, and delivers very deep gameplay mechanics that will make one hungry for more. 
Build up your Economy, place your turrets, upgrade them with add-ons, do Research and Development, build Battle Droids, use Orbital Strikes, do anything to stop those gruesome monsters from destroying your base!

It also features Toccata and Fugue with modern bits.
I don't know what you will do in this game, if you ever play it, but I can tell you, you will be facing thousands of monsters and hours of fun.

Recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038963412', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 2173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2173, 'last_played': 1403284071}
review:
9/10
Another Puppy game from the masters of genuine '80s retro styling. This time they turn their attention to Towers, Walls, and defending a base from a horde of Aliens.
What happens after the Space Invaders land? They advance on important human bases. How can humanity defend itself? By building towers to shoot at incoming aliens, of course!
With a simple "collect and refine" system for raising funds to keep building, and enough turret types and bonus boosts to make them work better, the levels can be tackled in various ways, and if they're too hard you can restart any level as an easier version. R+D happens between levels, with just a tad of plot and in-jokes. It's enough fun for the price, if you don't mind 8-bit style graphics (Which do really fit the general feel of teh game.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198077170314', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1385605320}
review: Let me start off by saying that this is is a great tower defense game. This is more difficult than many of the other tower defense games out there, yet easycomers or young children should not fret since their is an easy campaign in addition to the normal campaign. The game also features an endless mode, a survival mode, and a sandbox mode. The missions are non repetitive and usually include new maps with new spawning locations. The graphics, at times, can be beautiful, but are often hindered by the game's dark atmosphere. There are many things I found that set Revenge of the Titans apart from the other tower defense games. For starters the game places you in the game with a base that you must defend and roads leading from the spawn areas to the base. One would assume the enemies would follow these paths? That person would be wrong as the enemies travel along the path only to increase speed but swiftly disengage the path to attack nearby towers or form a direct path to the base. You heard me correctly, the towers are destructible, easily so in fact. The towers must also reload ammunition, slowly I should add. All these things add to the difficulty of the game, yet I am thoroughly pleased as this adds unique challenges and situations and surprises to the game which allow the game to remain a fun challenge, even after hours of playing. This leads me to the research screen. After each level, the player is rewarded with medals and a research point. The player can then use the point in the most advance research screen I have ever seen in an indie game. This screen feature a myriad of choices and subcategories. One fault i must find is that although the player can research towers, these said towers can not be upgraded, other than the placement of other upgrade towers nearby that can also stack in boosting power up to 4 times. After an hour or so of gameplay, I am throughly pleased with this game and recommend that others pick up this game if on sale, as I find some difficuly in justifying $9.99 for a game which resides in the overflooded quantity of tower defense games on the steam marketplace. Unless you are a large fan of tower defense games, I find that picking this game up for less thatn $5.00 is a sweet spot, as I was able to use the %75 off coupon to receive the game for $2.49.

review:
Saludos, comence en steam el 23 de septiembre y este fue mi 7 juego en steam el 23 de noviembre del 2013. 3 aÃ±os despues el juego sigue instalado en mi pc y divirtiendo. (2016) le doy a esta pequeÃ±a joya 9/10 su duraciÃ³n: uhn... llevo jugandolo 3 aÃ±os por ratos o cuando me quedo sin internet. yo dirÃ­a que en unas 5  horas (o menos en facil, pero en dificil es otra historia). el juego es re jugable, sobre todo cuando la pc esta en alguna tarea pesada.

+++++++++++++++++++++ LO BUENO +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

+++++ JUGABILIDAD Sencilla y un Defensa de torres. 

++++ buena mÃºsica y sonidos, 

++++ graficos bonitos sencillos y con buenos efectos especiales. 

la verdad me lo compre aprovechando un cupon, pero no me esperaba esta joya, altamente recomendado. le doy 9/10 

++++ la curva de aprendizaje.

++++ enemigos muy pero muy variados, voladores, terrestres, pesados, ligeros, medios, con escudos, fantasmas (intangibles no les afectan armas fisica, etc...)


--------------------------------------------- LO MALO --------------------------------------------------------------------

- lo unico negativo es la falta del espaÃ±ol - no spanish -.-  de resto no le he conseguido fallos xD, increiblemente no se me ha hecho repetitivo. ya que siempre hay nuevos niveles, armas, tecnologÃ­as que investigar, y muy pero muy variados enemigos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011146090', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1435530825}
review: Fun. But damn hard! Beutiful art style/graphics in a 2D way. It's a tower defense with more of a punch! But i hate the way the enimies don't follow the patch, they use there own route and follow the path 33% of the time. Recommend still!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972271187', 'num_games_owned': 890, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 1072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 903, 'last_played': 1618447652}
review:
Great tower defense game. Has  a 1950s with future sci-fi feel to it. Unlike most tower defense games the mobs come from various directions and are not restricted to on-rails paths. The game as been in bundles for awhile but is a fantastic game to get regardless. there is a upgrade/research tree for building different turrents and bot factories. Its a great gem you can play it for a long period of time or a short period of time. Unfortunately no sandbox (you have to buy seperate dlc for that) but it has a survival mode which has you going against and endless ever increasing wave of mobs.

In short: Great game,lots of fun, can be played for minutes or hours on end.Has a campaign,survival mode and if you willing to shell out for the sandbox with player made maps go for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974570403', 'num_games_owned': 543, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1402167849}
review:
i've been holding off on reviewing this game until i watched the films in the franchise first. i finally got around to that, so here is my review.

the story/lore starts off about a small redneck football team trying to make it into the big times. denzel washington does some great acting, so it works out well. (i don't understand why the title had "remember" in it, since it is the first movie. perhaps a hint for a prequel?)

the demand for more was so great that they signed on for a trilogy set in the same universe, but further in the past. it's about the dinosaur era where giants roamed the lands and fought with the greek. good films. definitely some hints in a post credit scene about where the football team got some of their genes from. definitely worth the popcorn i kettled.

i guess some people complained, because the original football weren't in those last few films. someone read our petition at change.org/petition i think because they made us a game. 

this time it is set in the future. it seems to be implied that a side-effect of being raised in the south, famous, ignorant, and ruggedly swole (thanks titan genes) is that you reproduce like crazy. the football titans have mated to the point of overpopulation, and they are mad. so they are getting their revenge. fun little game really. try to stop them from uprooting all cultures and installing footballism in its place. it's a race against time. 

are you big enough for the titans?

author: {'steamid': '76561197980813135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1371436629}
review:
I never would have thought tower defense and arcade-y gameplay could blend together so well, but Revenge of the Titans really pulled it off--there's a cool balance between meticulously planned defenses and frantically slapping down towers in a desperate bid for time, all tied up with a slick retro style.

All-around gameplay is excellent--the campaign is decently challenging to outright difficult, depending on the mission, and it's easy to see places where you can improve, though actually "maxing out" any given level is quite a feat, requiring a zen-like balance between defense and economy. The variety of enemies present also feels just right, and is one of the best places the game makes use of arcade gameplay sensabilties--you get no information about what enemies are incoming until they reach the battlefield, so the game is just as much about adapting your defenses on-the-fly as it is about big-picture planning, which feels really fresh for a tower defense game. The powerups are also an interesting twist, allowing you to be even more flexible--which gave the designers an excuse to make the game just that much more frantic.

Outside of the battles themselves, the tech tree you develop between missions is pretty nice; almost every new weapon unlock feels like an important decision, though it's a little unfortunate that many of the "unlock new tree" techs feel unrewarding, as they only offer the promise of cool upgrades next time around.

The game's aesthetics are fantastic, and make excellent use of the 8-bit style, further  complemented by the badass soundtrack and powerful sound effects--your weapons sound dangerous, the monsters sound terrifying, and the notifications and powerups sound like the coolest arcade game you've never played. There's a sort of vibrancy to this game that is hard to come by.

All in all, this game is a hell of a lot of bang for your buck--well worth the full price, but if it's on sale, you don't have an excuse.

review: This game is a proof that a Tower Defense can be a great and an actual game. You have to research and actually think when building, not just spam the map with buildings. It also has some RTS elements (units later in the game, resource mining). Visuals are great, music is catchy. A great game indeed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992886766', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 969, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 697, 'last_played': 1370922720}
review:
Sorta a fusion of tower defense and an RTS, this game is all about researching new tech as you advance through dozen of levels and blasting hundreds of baddies in hopes of not being overwhelmed! 

Enemies don't follow certain paths all of the time and you're free to build pretty much wherever you want so each level will be tackled differently from player to player. The research tree is pretty extensive and will have a major impact on how the campaign progresses for you - making bad research choices can really screw you over! 

All in all its a pretty deep and fun TD/RTS game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197968658621', 'num_games_owned': 993, 'num_reviews': 446, 'playtime_forever': 1706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1665, 'last_played': 1686092084}
review:
[i]---see where this game landed on my tower defense tier list beneath this review!---[/i]


Extremely hectic Tower defense with a simple yet charming art style.  Quite different to alot of other tower defense games, It almost feels reminiscent of taking on base defense duties in an RTS like Red Alert.  You will feel totally overwhelmed most of the time scrambling between selling buildings, patching up areas of your defense that are going to be overrun, clicking powerups.. Constantly I find myself forced into making instant decisions, whilst my brain is pleading for 10 seconds to think.

[b]A Tier:[/b]  Fieldrunners 2 | Dungeon Warfare | Warstone TD | Orcs Must Die! | [b]Revenge of the Titans[/b] | Plants Vs Zombies

[b]B Tier:[/b]  Unstoppable Gorg | Prime World Defenders | Dungeon of the Endless |  Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal

review: An excellent tower defense game, with a great soundtrack and waaaaaay too many customization options for its own good. Consider it the XCOM of tower defense games - your early choices can impact your later ones, you get bonuses and benefits for playing as efficient / smart as possible, and it gets very brutal by the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017746934', 'num_games_owned': 1643, 'num_reviews': 484, 'playtime_forever': 751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 751, 'last_played': 1375816997}
review:
Get your ass to Mars!
Quite likely the best tower defense game on Steam! I hate tower defense as a genre and I generally suck at strategy games of any kind, yet, I played this to the very end.
It's a lot more freeform than most TD games and the art style, atmosphere and soundtrack add a lot to the full package.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972763622', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1335769200}
review:
A very different, very frustrating, and very satisfying (in most cases) tower defense game. Your resources and research choices persist through each level, giving you a real sense of both expression and tension as you make your way through the campaign.
Unfortunately, enemies pop up with little warning that the developers designed for very specific methods of dispatching, and if you haven't researched those methods you're shit out of luck and have to start from 3 or more previous missions to re-organize your tech tree, so instead of the persistent tech tree encouraging interesting expression it turns into a trial-and-error situation where there is a specific path you're supposed to follow.

Otherwise, the interface is sleek, the visuals and audio are great, and the actual design of any given research upgrade is interesting. I'd definitely recommend it at $10.

review: This is a super addictive game. Revenge of the Titans plays like a tower defense game, but has a lot more strategy and a lot fewer resources to defend with. I will warn you that you can't redo levels without reseting your game, and you can't start a new game (even on a seperate computer) without erasing your current game. Despite the game save issues,Revenge of the Titans is a fun, challenging game that will grab and hold your attention.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000568601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1094, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1009, 'last_played': 1635535968}
review:
It's tower defence in a creepy-cute package. It's a definite must-buy if you're a fan of tower defence and, more importantly, a fan of a real challenge.

The mechanics of this game are easy enough to learn, but as the levels progress it becomes clear that mastering them is the only way to truly win. Resources are present, but always feel scarce. The aliens can destroy your units with a mere touch, and the 'bosses' require either a couple tries, or a lot of luck.

The game does seem to reward certain playstyles, which is fine, but could become frustrating. If you're not a fan of starting over, then this is not the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009288616', 'num_games_owned': 795, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 1175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1386909550}
review:
A fun Tower Defense-esque game with a few twists.

Basically you have a good selection of weapons and upgrades, and enemy type is fairly varied. The biggest difference between this and most Tower Defense games is that the enemies don't always follow the same path; sometimes they follow roads that give them movement speed boosts, but other times they will try avoiding your turrets or going straight for your vulnerable structures.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042237959', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 241, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1327219200}
review: Frustration!! This game despite the cute and simple premise of a tower defense game is extremely hard. You'll get to level 40 and realised you didn't save enough money from the first few levels to pass. Whilst it was fun to get there, there is little incentive for me to go back and save the extra $100 per level just so I have that $4,000 I can pass level 40. Challenging and somewhat fun.. I recommend Orcs Must Die over this as a tower defense game 5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197964009814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 339, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 86400}
review:
I played this before it was on Steam and I must say... by the time you left the Moon it got really really hard!

Basically this is a Tower Defense game that you collect resources and kill everything before it reaches your base.

Aftter each level ~ you can select a power up.    Looks awesome, plays awesome, and its really fun!   

Originally the game was very difficult and unforgiving if you made any poor choices in power ups, but I've been informed that this has been changed to be more fair.  I had a good time playing it when it was difficult, but now it should be much better!

author: {'steamid': '76561197968430427', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1331020800}
review:
Really frustrating game. I'm 3/5ths of the way through the game and have discovered I've researched the "wrong" techs with no way to stop the Level 30 boss. Now I've got to restart from level one again.

If you're going to let the player select which techs to research, then make sure you don't let them go down a tech dead end with no way to progress in the game! Poor game design!

author: {'steamid': '76561197966549849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1331539200}
review:
I don't usually dig tower defense type games, however I picked this up as part of the humble indy game bundle and discovered that Revenge of the Titans is NOT your typical tower defense.  The research trees are complex enough to really make you think about your choices in the long term.  You also carry your cash from level to level with the ability to go back to a previous point and start from that previous area.  This is a brilliant design decision, because if you get stuck, its so easy to go back to try to clear a level better for more cash, or to research down a different tree.  The non-boxy placement of turrets and mappy levels are reminiscent of warcraft and starcraft, which turns out to be a good thing as placement stays dynamic, and you scroll around the map to keep up with the battle and grab powerups.

Basically this is non-tower defensey tower defense, and the game is far better for it.

review:
Cute is what comes to mind when i see this game.
"Holy shit i'm gonna die" is another. Fun, but the fact that the terrain is completely open and the monsters are not guaranteed to take the road makes it difficult to plan.
Still, i really enjoyed it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960961621', 'num_games_owned': 712, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1107, 'last_played': 1404701638}
review: Steep learning curve initially, but an amazing indie take on the tried and true Tower Defense genre. Revenge of the Titans takes many of the staples of the TD genre and recombobulates them into something fresh. A slick art style and a solid soundtrack make this game worth playing through several times over. RECOMMENDED!

author: {'steamid': '76561197960603292', 'num_games_owned': 406, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1321, 'last_played': 1335250800}
review:
This is a helluva fun tower defense game, I like the storyline and endless war modes, the technology "tree" is a great addition that gives you the sensation that you're winning the game your way (and offers replayability).  If you're a fan of tower defense you owe it to yourself to buy this at any sale price.

Well, once you get over the idea of "clever" enemies... frustrating the first hundred times... then a new an interesting challenge!

author: {'steamid': '76561198055747418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1513815939}
review:
Sencillo turret defense en apariencia, pero mas y mas complejo a medida que te metes en el juego, tanto por la creciente dificultad como por la variedad de opciones a la hora de investigar mejoras. Â¿La fase extra navideÃ±a? Una jodida locura. Divertidisima, aunque solo apta para masoquistas

Por cierto Â¿Soy el unico al que la recogida de recursos recuerda brutalmente al Starcraft?

author: {'steamid': '76561197992615223', 'num_games_owned': 429, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1338620400}

One of the best TDs out there, also a plus for the Stanley Kubrick-esque soundtrack.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978520784', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1591630278}
review:
This is the most frusatrating game I have ever played lacking the BASIC ability to even change the god damned difficulty setting. You can only do so by LOSING A game 5 times until it's at the right difficulty to play it. The challenges are annoying as f*** and even more infuriating. Even if you're just trying to play the game and have fun you can't because all you'll end up doing is wanting to go punch a baby.

Don't buy it. Just keep walking!

author: {'steamid': '76561197969965024', 'num_games_owned': 416, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1649647911}
review:
This is a really fun and stylish little tower defense game that I thoroughly enjoy.  It is not easy!  A complete steal on sale, well worth it when I paid full price.
I liked the art design so much I bought the rest of the developers games off his site.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965445333', 'num_games_owned': 586, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 687, 'last_played': 1366700400}
review: Revenge of the Titans is a fantastic specimen of classic tower defense, styled in a completely unique and appealing fashion. The difficulty ramps up pretty quick, making the later worlds mind-meltingly challenging, but no matter how far you manage to get, this game is nothing but enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975071093', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 731, 'last_played': 1384027862}
review: Good game. I enjoy the new changes to the typical tower defense mechanics and gameplay which is quite an interesting take on the genre and I like it. Love the art style throughout the entire game. The technology tree is also very nice and a great addition that compliments the game well. The campaign is nice and difficult and the challenges on the side give some decent replay-ability. I only wish that I could play co-op with a friend because that would be amazing in this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960275226', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5105, 'last_played': 1586696184}
review: Build your base, defend it against the Titans, explore new stuff in the tech tree and then: do it all over again in the next challenging level of Revenge Of The Titans. It is as simple as that! But it is also very addictive gameplay. By now I have clocked in more than 50 hours ingame, more than I can say of other (more mainstream) titles. The concept of tower defense games may sound simple to you, but make no mistake, the learning curve for this game can be steep sometimes. At least, you can always go back a few levels and experiment with other items in your tech tree and then spend countless hours trying new tactics with different weapons. However, should you be stuck on a particular level, you can always ask around in the steam forums, the developers are very active there and give excellent insight into the game mechanics (e.g. why you should upgrade a turret, how to maximize profits from mining crystals, etc.). To cut a long story short: I love this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030141391', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 455, 'last_played': 1605794896}
review:
Very unique tower defense game - and for one core reason. This is an extremely rare game that [b]actively plays against you.[/b] There are no rigid challenges, maps, and sets of enemies - a lot of rules can change on the fly. If you're doing too well - game says "challenge accepted" and starts to generate more difficult maps and include a bit more enemies. If you're abusing one particular tactic, say, blocking roads by barricades - the game will add some limited amount of brains to enemies so they'll start to avoid roads more often. And so on.

The net result is that every level is always TOUGH, no matter how you play. Although of course the AI isn't omnipotent and infallible, and there are ways that you can use to overcome it - but unlike most games, finding those is pretty tricky.

PS: And if the challenge is too much for you - yes, you still [b]can[/b] lower the difficulty.
